passages.name: lex gold
passages.text:
Lex turned as soon as I got close enough and smiled, so warm I could almost feel it. "Mari! Get over here. Look at this!" She said, pointing at the wall. She looked giddy. I hadn't seen her look this happy in months. "Mari. The wall…" She repeated. I blushed, hoping she couldn't see it under the dim light. I followed her arm and gasped as I saw the wall. It glimmered, light tossed back and forth across veins of golden stone. Lex grinned and I <>only felt my stomach drop. I had to be the one to tell her.
  • [[I told her about the fool's gold.|tell her gold][$lex+=1]]
  • [[She could ask Don Aquiles.|ask Don aquiles]]
  • [[It was better if I just kept my mouth shut.|keep mouth shut lex]]
<>grinned with her. "Gold," she whispered, almost reverent. "We need to do something about this. Dig some out or something!"
  • [[We're not miners!|not miners]]
  • [[Yeah! If we look around, we're sure to find something!|find something]]
  • [[Maybe we should ask Don Aquiles first?|don aquiles first]]
<>

links.text: I told her about the fool's gold.
It was better if I just kept my mouth shut.
Yeah! If we look around, we're sure to find something!
Maybe we should ask Don Aquiles first?

passages.name: don aquiles sent
passages.text:
"Don Aquiles sent me," I half-lied. He'd told me where she was, sure, but I'd come here for the jackalope's proof, for some glimpse of understanding of this place. Lex frowned. "To help me?" "No, the other way around. I mean, you seem to be talking to him a lot. Did he tell you where they were?" I asked. She shook her head. "No, he said that'd come later. He just wanted me to explore the place tonight. Won't even let me sign a contract till tomorrow." I raised an eyebrow. "Contract?" Lex grinned, all teeth. "Summer job. Pretty good pay, and free room and board. Get myself some cash before college, you know?" "So you want to stay? What if it's a trap?!" I said. Lex looked at me. I looked back. She raised an eyebrow. I looked away. "You know that doesn't make any sense at all, right? Wouldn't it be trying harder to keep us here if it was? The place isn't exactly a paradise." I thought of the ugly curtains, the run down cars in the parking lot. I thought of the peace and the calm and the endless night sky.
  • [[Yeah, I guess it's not.|yeah guess not trap]]
  • [[But maybe it is?|maybe it is][$lext+=1]]

passages.name: smoking woman
passages.text: <<if $smoke>><<goto "smoking second">><<else>><<goto "smoking woman 1">><<endif>>

passages.name: sleeping in
passages.text:
"Sleeping in sounds like a great idea." I said, as we stepped out of the car. Becky smiled at me, and Lex rolled her eyes. She knew she was outnumbered.

Looking up, I took in the motel sign again. We'd seen several like it on our trip here. Googie architecture, it was called. Swooping lines and visions of yesterday's future.

This one was a little more boring than most. The sign didn't even seem to be animated.

Still, all we needed was a place to stay. We took our bags, and walked into the [[MOTEL OFFICE|arriving at lobby]].

passages.name: keep mouth shut lex
passages.text:
It was better if I just kept my mouth shut. "That's great, Lex." I said. "But I've already looked around and I didn't find anything." But she could always tell when I was lying. She didn't need to know the details. She just knew I hadn't found anything good. Lex let out a soft sigh, running her fingers over the golden stone. "Shame, I… I honestly thought…"
  • [[What did you think?|what did you think][$lex+=1]]
  • [[Let's not. Let's not think about this anymore.|lets not think]]

links.text: Let's not. Let's not think about this anymore.

passages.name: what did you think
passages.text:
"What did you think?" I asked, stepping closer. Maybe there was something I could say. Something I could do that would make her feel better. Anything. She just shook her head, turning away from me. "It just sucks. This whole thing just sucks!" Her shout echoed in the hallway. "I should have known that even the gold in this place would be fake." She sighed, long and low. "Some trap." <3>>
[[➥|some trap reveal]]
<>
[[➥|some trap conceal]]
<>

passages.name: post phonebooth jack
passages.text:
The Jackalope was standing in front of the wall of evidence, tail twitching, foot thumping. It didn't turn when I walked in, didn't even seem to notice until I said, "Hey." I never knew what sounds rabbits made, but apparently Jackalopes make the auditory equivalent of ASFKJDLKFJDSL. "You! How'd you get in here?!" His eyes glowed orange in the dim light, wide and paranoid. He didn't blink. Could rabbits blink? "The door was open," I said. "Oh," he said. "Well, did you find the phone booth? Did it work?!"
  • [[I let him down easy.|down easy]]
  • [[Of course it worked!|of course worked]]

passages.name: becky quarter yes
passages.text:
Becky looked at me, then back at the quarter. "What?" "You need this more than I do. You actually have someone to talk to on the outside," I said. Becky looked back at the impossible phone booth, here in the middle of nowhere, then back at the quarter. She seemed more frightened of the quarter than of anything else we'd seen tonight. "You're the one who said talking is good." I reminded her. She took a breath, looking at the disk. "And you'll talk to Lex?" "I'll think about it." I promised, and I would. Just maybe, not tonight. Just maybe, not ever. Who knew. She nodded, and took the quarter in her hand. "Do you want me to stay?" I asked. She shook her head. "No, I…This is something I should do alone." I should have felt worse, leaving her out in the middle of the desert, in the light of a lonely street lamp, at a phone booth that shouldn't exist. But like everything in this place, it just felt like just the right side of wrong. I looked back a few times, peering at her through the tinted glass. She was hunched over, crying. I could tell, even if I couldn't see her tears. Guess the jackalope was wrong. The phone did work. <>
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: don keys
passages.text:
"Uh, have you seen my keys?" I asked, a bit nervous to be asking. "No, I can print you a replacement though. 207, right?" "My car keys," I clarified. "Oh… No, perdon. That I'm afraid I can't help with."
[[➥|lobby]]

passages.name: thanks
passages.text:
I hate the way my name sounds on American tongues. The a's move forward into the nose, the e's becomes sneers. My parents should have thought of this, of the fact that I was born in the US and would live in the US before they left me with a name I'd constantly have to correct people about. But I didn't correct him today. I was just too tired for it. "Thanks," I said, not meaning a word. He smiled, and handed over a little plastic keychain, with bright white letters that read ROOM 207. "There's coffee here after five. Stairs are down the hall. Pool's closed for repairs." We nodded, and I could feel how tired we all were. It was time to rest.
[[➥|bs lobby]]

passages.name: I think I will
passages.text:
"Yeah," I said, pushing myself up. "I think I will. You going to head to bed anytime tonight?" Dean smiled and shook his head. "The night's just getting started. In fact," he stopped, looking at his wrist-watch. "The cactus is about to bloom." Here he gestured out towards the hotel sign, a three pronged-cactus lit up in tacky neon-green. But that's all there was. There was no glint or extra neon tubing to herald a bloom, or even any animation. But as I watched, it happened anyway.
[[➥|bloom]]

passages.name: tell her gold
passages.text:
"Yeah, I found something," I said. She looked at me for a long time. Even in the dim light of the tunnel, she could tell. "It's not gold, is it?" I shook my head. "Pyrite, fool's gold. I found some old flyers from the ads they ran, big tourist attraction." I hated saying it, hated the way her face dimmed, her smile vanished. She let out a soft sigh, running her fingers over the golden stone. "Shame, I… I honestly thought…"
  • [[What did you think?|what did you think][$lex+=1]]
  • [[Let's not. Let's not think about this anymore.|lets not think]]

links.text: Let's not. Let's not think about this anymore.

passages.name: exit shed
passages.text:
We walked together, back to the Cactus Blue. Under its light, we parted ways. She said she was heading back to the room, and I needed to talk to the jackalope.\n\n
[[➥|pool]]

passages.name: dean flower
passages.text:
"What's up with the flower?" I asked. "Do I look like a botanist to you? I don't know, it just turns on at night. Brings the whole place back to life." I pursed my lips. That wasn't an answer.
    <>

    • <>

  • [["How long have you been here?"|dean long]]
  • [["What do you think of the motel?"|dean motel]]
  • [["What do you think of the other guests?"|dean guests]]
  • [[No more questions.|no more q dean]]

passages.name: fourth fork
passages.text:
In the ninth grade, Lex and I were placed in the same freshman art class. It was a small comfort; neither of us were what anyone would call "artsy". Still, we found our preferred mediums. Lex took to sketching, said she liked that it was fluid, but not messy like charcoal.

I chose photography, for a while.

Now, faced with [[LEX|lex gold]] staring at the rough stone wall, dark skin lit only by flickering lantern light, I itched to pick a camera back up.

passages.name: looking
passages.text:
"What am I looking for?" I asked. "The books. They should be full of people who never signed out, people who never left." He said. "There are at least a few of those," I said, thinking of Dean, of The Smoking Woman. "More than a few, a trend. Proof." He said the last word reverently, eyes glinting with fanaticism.
  • [[What shed?|what shed]]
  • [[I could just ask.|just ask]]
  • [[I'm ready.|im ready]]

passages.name: nothing to do with this
passages.text:
"What's going on between me and Lex has nothing to do with this." I said, wanting to walk faster, wishing our arms weren't linked. Just a moment ago, I would have done anything to keep her, to not lose Becky to a new college, to new friends. Now, I just wanted to get away. "It has plenty to do with it. We're talking about talking, and how you're no good at it. I get it, it's hard, but we wouldn't have thought differently of you." I rolled my eyes. "Yeah, cause you're really proving that right now." Becky bristled. I felt it, like a current through our linked arms. "I'm not… Mari, this isn't like that. I don't care that you're a lesbian, and neither would Lex. But you never told us. You never tell us anything." "I'm not-" "Don't lie to my face, Mari," She broke away. We stopped walking, standing in the middle of the highway.
  • [[I felt panic creep up my throat. This was exactly what I wanted to avoid.|panic becky]]
  • [[I felt rage bubble under my skin. She just didn't understand.|rage becky]]
  • [[I felt tired. I could try to explain, but would it work?|tired becky]]

links.text: I felt panic creep up my throat. This was exactly what I wanted to avoid.
I felt rage bubble under my skin. She just didn't understand.
I felt tired. I could try to explain, but would it work?

passages.name: maybe a bit
passages.text:
"Maybe for a bit," I said, and Becky beamed. She scooted to the side, patting the bed next to her. I crawled up, laying near her as the man on the screen gushed about his new knife set. We sat there in silence for a while. It reminded me of a thousand other nights, a thousand other movies. And all of that was coming to an end. "I'm going to miss you," I said. I think it was the first time I'd said anything about it, and I regretted it immediately. Saying it made it real. Becky didn't look at me. "You don't have to, you know? I mean, not yet. We're staying here for a while." I could almost hear the brittleness under her skin, brought to light under the cactus blue.
  • [[It doesn't work that way.|work that way][$becky+=1]]
  • [[Yeah. I guess.|yeah I guess]]

passages.name: pk parklot
passages.text:
A fading, neon flower glowed above the sign that read Cactus Blue Motel. It was unattached to any wires, shifting like a living thing, with every breathe of desert air. It seemed tired, and wilted.

The motel itself was wilting too, both on the lobby side [[(ROOMS 101-103)|pk f11]], and the side where my rooms were [[(ROOMS 104-110).|pk f12]]

Becky's car was sitting in a spot near the west end of the motel. The beat up sedan from before was gone, replaced with a bright blue Thunderbird paint looking faded, and chipped.

Dean sat next to his motorcycle, waiting for me to go upstairs, and talk to the others.

The Highway was dusty, grainy, and inky black.

passages.name: band 1
passages.text:
Back in middle school, I'd joined band with the vague dream of becoming a rock star. I was eleven, and I didn't know anything about the real world, or real jobs, or the failure of even realistic dreams. But when I dreamt about that rock star future, the woman who opened the door was what I would dream of. Wild hair, ripped jeans, wrapped up in a take on the world stance, with a backdrop of drums. And even better, her eyes lit up at the sight of me. "Hey, you're new, aren't you?" She said, starting to grin widely. I couldn't stop my blush as I nodded. "Awesome! Come in then!" The beds were pushed up against the wall to make space for the instruments and sheet music spread out on the floor. Introductions went swiftly, seeing as nobody gave me their name. There was The Drummer, The Bassist, The Guitarist, and The Singer. Together, they called themselves The Band. "You play anything?" The Singer asked. <><>
  • [["I was in band for a while."|band while]]
  • [["Not really."|not really]]

links.text: "I was in band for a while."

passages.name: second fork
passages.text:
The first thing I saw was the poster: young man giving a thumbs up in front of a mushroom cloud. The room was too brightly lit, not the kind fluorescent of outside, but burning and garish. The walls were lined with mostly maple syrup and pickled nopalitos. Other than that, nothing of interest.
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: long band
passages.text:
"How long have you been here?" The Drummer counted out the beat, one, two, three, four. "I dunno what year is it." The Singer said. "2016," I said. "Dude! We passed Y2K! Awesome, is the world still okay? It didn't explode or anything did it?" Well that dated them nicely. "Yeah, the world's fine."
    <>

passages.name: smoking excuse me
passages.text:
"Well excuse me, I think there's reason to stare." "The face thing? Yeah. I suppose. Don't worry about it. You new?" I nodded. "Yeah, me and my friends…" "Friends," She scoffed. "We'll see how they hold up. They got any reason to be sticking around?" Becky and Lex both had futures waiting out there. Fancy colleges, and lots of plans. "No, not really." "They'll probably check out tomorrow then, but you… you look like someone with a reason to stay. Are you?"
  • [["I am."|I am smoking]]
  • [["I don't know."|dont know smoking][$go+=1]]

passages.name: getting some air
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Second FLoor, Rooms 203-210

You never got skies this clear in Houston. I doubt they happened in New York or Palo Alto either, but in Houston they definitely didn't. The city lights there faded up into the sky, eating up the dim light of the stars until all that was left is black and clouds. But here, the black was dotted with stars, and painted with the bright blue of the Milky Way. The closest thing to a cloud were the thin wisps of smoke, rising from the cigarette of the boy in the [[PARKING LOT|parking lot]]. He looked up at me, and waved. Guess I wasn't the only one who couldn't sleep.

passages.name: maybe it is
passages.text:
"But maybe it is?" I said. I was trying to poke holes in this because I had to, because I wanted to know this place, to understand it. Lex didn't care as much for understanding; she just wanted things to "make sense". I used to think they were the same thing. "It's not, Mari. If this were a trap it'd be… I don't know, it'd be wonderful, not just weirdly average." "But we all want to stay, don't we?" I thought she wouldn't be able to argue that. I underestimated her ability to argue. "That doesn't have anything to do with this place." "Wouldn't it be safer just to check, to look around?" I said. Was it so bad that I just wanted to be sure? "Alright," she said, giving in for once."I'm going down this way. We'll cover more ground like that." She said, and wandered off ahead towards some of the further branches.
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: StoryTitle
passages.text: Cactus Blue Motel

passages.name: lex drive
passages.text:
Lex was driving. She liked driving the most out of all of us, so when she said she'd take the wheel, we never argued. If it were up to her, she'd have taken over this whole trip. But it was all of ours, together, and she relented. Still, the parts she had planned were impeccable. Neat, organized itineraries worthy of someone as type-A as she was. Still, that which organized our trip also meant it wasn't easy for her to deal with the car rule where shotgun controlled the music. "Okay, that's enough Hamilton. Change the music," she said.
  • [[I changed the music.|me music]]
  • [[Becky changed the music.|becky music]]

passages.name: bunker
passages.text:
The Middle of the Desert - A Run Down Shed

A lightbulb flickered inside the run down shed. On the floor, the heavy metal lid had been unlocked and opened. There was nothing in this room. Only the hole. <> And the only way in was [[DOWN.|down]]

passages.name: dont know call
passages.text:
"I don't know who we should call, but we have to try it out," I said. "We have to see if there's a way to reach outside this place." "And if there isn't?" Becky said. She didn't seem nervous at all, why wasn't she nervous? "I guess we'll figure it out then." I said lamely. I wasn't much good at thinking ahead.
    <>

The Singer said. Drummer agreed with a drum riff. I smiled weakly. I wasn't sure what that meant, but I could still ask them some questions.

passages.name: yeah I guess
passages.text:
"Yeah, I guess." I said. "I'm still trying to figure this place out." I didn't know what it was I wanted. Not really. Not anything besides the vague desire to not be back in Houston. "Then let's do that," Becky said, sitting up. I heard what she didn't say. "Well, I uh…heard that there was this phone booth, out in the desert. It's why I came actually. To get some quarters." Becky paused. "A phone booth?"
  • [["Yeah. Come with me?"|becky come with me][$becky+=1]]
  • [["Yeah, but you can stay if you like."|becky stay]]

links.text: "Yeah, but you can stay if you like."

passages.name: what now
passages.text:
"What now?" I asked. It couldn't be any more convincing than any of his reasons before. He hopped up close, orange eyes looking right in to me. He paused. I blinked. He didn't. "Where are your car keys?" My hand went to my pocket, empty.
  • [[They're gone.|keys gone]]
  • [[I never had them.|never had them]]

passages.name: insomnia
passages.text:
I couldn't sleep.

Maybe it was because the curtains in the room didn't close all the way, so the room was lit up by the faint haze of the neon outside. Maybe it was the way the LED on the fire alarm lit up at irregular intervals in a pattern I couldn't follow, even though I spent a while watching.

Maybe it was the sound of Becky muttering in her sleep. Maybe it was Lex's silence.

Maybe it was me.

Whatever it was, I wasn't getting any sleep tonight. I might as well [[GO OUTSIDE|getting some air]] for a bit, get some air.

passages.name: yes band
passages.text:
"Yeah, probably." I said. Odds looked good so far. "Great! We can't wait. We'll probably write a new song with you." The Singer said. The Drummer agreed with a drum riff. I smiled weakly. I never had written a song before. Well, we'd have time for that. I could still ask them some questions.

passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Second Floor, Rooms 201-203

The [[STAIRS|pk f11]] lead back down to the first floor. To the right, there are three rooms: 203 : Vacant 202 : Vacant <>201: DO NOT DISTURB, and a locked door that wouldn't open to me.<>[[201 : DO NOT DISTURB.|jack goodbye]]<> After that, an ice machine sat in the spot where another room might have once been. The [[REST OF THE ROOMS (204-210)|pk f22]] stretch out to the left.

passages.name: out room all go
passages.text:
We walked fast, the sun already peeking past the dusty mesa in the distance. Piling everything back in the car, I allowed myself one last look at Dean. He looked so disappointed, cigarette drooping. Maybe, another time, things might have been different. But this time, we all got in to the car, and Lex drove us away. I looked out the window as we drove, at the rising sun and the fading, neon, cactus bloom. I watched until the sky was pink, and the motel was out of sight. Then I turned around, facing forward. There were still 750 miles to Santa Monica after all.
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: dean here
passages.text:
"How did you end up here?" Dean let out a perfect circle of smoke. It highlighted a flickering star, then faded into the night. "Long story short, was trying to get away from my dad. He wants me to take over the family business, boring. I decided to go for a drive and well…" "You ever think of going back home?" Dean laughed. "Dad can drag me there himself if he really wants me back. Until then, I'll pass."
    <>

"Hey, have you seen my keys?" I really hoped I hadn't left them here. He turned from the typewriter, still blank, and shook his head. "No. But if you talk to The Don, he'll give you a fresh copy." "I meant my car keys." "Oh." He turned back to his manuscript. Helpful.

passages.name: smoking no more q

I didn't have any more questions for now. She raised a hand as I walked away. I thought it would be a wave. Instead she took another drag. I couldn't tell if she was looking at me go.

passages.name: band trap
passages.text:
"Do you think this place is a trap?" I asked. The Bassist stopped plucking out her beat. The Drummer went still. "Nah," said the Singer. "This place is great! All the time in the world to do what you want. Besides, if it was, it'd be way more Hotel California. Instead it's more Piano Man, you know? Sharing a drink they call loneliness." That made sense, but as I was nodding The Guitarist kicked some sheet paper towards me. I couldn't read the notes, but the title was Hell in Mundanity. I looked back up at him, but he was playing out the opening to Hotel California, and didn't look up.
[[➥|f11]]

passages.name: first fork
passages.text:
In the tunnels, there was darkness. Not shadow, not the absence of light, but the absorbing of it. The yellowing bulbs tried to pierce the darkness. Tried to reach forward, forward. And failed. I didn't try. I really didn't try.
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: all go ending
passages.text:
"Then I'm leaving too," Becky said, though she sounded like my choice had very little to do with hers.

Lex paused, and looked over the both of us. "I suppose, we all arrived together. We should all leave together."

Becky grinned, and hopped over to our bed, pulling us into a hug. I breathed into it, pure and clean. We could do this together, I realized. Leave this place and its banal temptations.

"Let's get out of here before the sun rises," Lex said. Becky just started packing, and soon we all walked [[OUT OF THE ROOM.|out room all go]]

passages.name: don here
passages.text:
"How did you end up here?" He leaned back, letting out a long sigh. "Oh I can barely remember. They found gold out in California, and I figured I'd make my fortune. Never did make it. How did that end up going?" I didn't know much about the gold rush, so I told him what I did. "Some people got pretty rich, other people didn't." "Isn't that the truth?" He said. "No, I prefer this much better. The Cactus Blue takes care of herself mostly. Don't even need to charge for the people who decide to stay. I figure it's the least I can do since it's so easy to maintain." "She, uh, takes care of herself?" I asked. Was the Motel alive? He just smiled and shrugged. "Misterios, Maria Elena. Some questions can't be answered."
    <>

passages.name: books don
passages.text:
"I was wondering if I could take a look at your sign-in books?" I said. He wrinkled his nose. It made his whole face crumple in a decidedly unpleasant way. "I'm not sure, Maria Elena. Many of my guests stay here because they do not wish to be disturbed." I hadn't found that to be the case at all, but I kept going. "Not recent ones, but old ones. This place seems to have been around forever, I was just wondering about some of it's history." His face relaxed, smoothed over like a wind passed over it. He smiled. His face wasn't lined then. "Oh! Wonderful. It's so nice to see you girls taking an interest in the old place. I keep all the old records down in the shed. Just don't go too far down, you might get lost." "Thanks," I said. Don Aquiles nodded. "Let me know if there's anything else you need." He said.
[[➥|lobby]]

passages.name: out room you stay they go
passages.text:
We walked fast, the sun already peeking past the dusty mesa in the distance, and piled everything into the car. Shutting the trunk, Lex walked up to me. "Not too late to change your mind," she said. I paused. I wondered, if I said something, would she ask me to go with her. To stay by her side. But a movement distracted me. It was Dean, waving and smiling. I smiled back. "Nah, I'll be okay." The sky was already turning pink by the time they drove off. I walked slowly and sat next to Dean on the curb. Above us, the cactus bloom was flickering, neon dying in the dawn light. "You're gonna love it here. I promise," he said, wrapping an arm around my shoulder. He smelled like leather, and smoke and I nodded. "Yeah, you know what… I think I will."
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: furniture
passages.text:
"Are you even allowed on the furniture?" I asked. Did Don Aquiles know about this? Did anyone? Was this normal here? His nose twitched in annoyance, ears swiveling. "Oh you're laughing it up now, but look, LOOK!" He hopped over to the evidence wall, one antler tugging at a long red string. "See, the whole place is a trap. People check in, but they never check out!" I squint over at the wall. There are newspapers, some of them older than me, and photos, but nothing that seems decipherable. He must have noticed my confusion because he kept going. "Fine! I'll prove it to you!" "How?" I asked, but he was already convincing me just by having put the idea in my head. Pushing Daisies isn't that good. Lex could never give up on a schedule. "By showing you how trapped it is. You know phones don't work here. They don't want you reaching the outside world." His nose twitched, and he looked to the door, nervous that we'd be found. "But I still haven't tested the last one, the last phone. It's a pay phone, down east by the highway, still in the light of the motel. If I'm right, you could go out there, and it wouldn't let you call." "And if it does?" He already had me and he knew it. He seemed sure it wouldn't. I was less sure, about that, about anything. But now I had to check it out.
[[➥|f21]]

passages.name: knock
passages.text:
I knocked and they stopped talking. The door opened to reveal the manager, a vivacious, older latino, eyes glimmering under the blue light. He looked completely different from the man who had rented out the room. Lively, where the other was pale and tired. Behind him, Lex sat at the desk, looking smug. "Maria Elena! Welcome, welcome," he said, my name flowing smoothly from his lips. "Lex, why don't we finish this up later? Explore for a while, get to know the motel. There's no rush at all, you know." Lex stood, the veritable cat that had gotten the cream. "I know. Still, I don't think I'll change my mind." The manager laughed and moved aside, letting Lex out of his cramped little office. "Yes, I can certainly see that. Still, spend some time with your friend, enjoy. I'll still be here until morning." "Thank you, Don Aquiles," Her mouth twisted wrongly around the q sound. High School Spanish and staying over at my place had never been enough to lose Lex's accent. "You can just call me The Don, most people do." He replied, in that easy way I was familiar with. We shared a moment, two people with names unpronounceable in English. "Have a nice evening, girls." He shut the door and Lex turned to me, eyes bright. I'd come here to convince her to stay, but to be honest, she didn't look like she needed a lot of convincing. <>
  • [[I asked what she thought about the motel.|lex motel 1]]
  • [[I asked her what she thought about Don Aquiles.|lex aquiles 1]]
  • [[I asked about Becky.|lex becky 1]]

passages.name: you go lex go room
passages.text:
Becky looked at me in shock, but Lex, she looked guilty.

"Me too," she said.

"But you said you'd wanted to stay," said Becky, almost in a whine. "You wanted to take the job. And Mari, you wanted to stay because…"

And her words died out, because she realized she had no idea why I wanted to stay. 

"It'll be fine. We'll come by on the drive back." If she was still here. If we could find it again. "We'll swing by and pick you up."

Becky didn't believe me. I barely did. But she helped us pack anyway, and we all, solemnly, [[LEFT THE ROOM.|you go lex go out room]]

passages.name: parklot
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Parking Lot

A neon flower glowed above the sign that read [[CACTUS BLUE MOTEL|cactus bloom]]. It was unattached to any wires, shifting like a living thing, with every breath of desert air. The motel itself was lively as well both on the side of the lobby [[(ROOMS 101-103)|f11]], and the side where my rooms were [[(ROOMS 104-110).|f12]] [[BECKY'S CAR|beckys car]] was sitting in a spot near the west end of the motel. The beat up sedan from before was gone, replaced with a bright blue [[THUNDERBIRD.|thunderbird]] [[DEAN|dean]] sat next to his motorcycle, the only one on the lot. Even the [[HIGHWAY|highway]] looked fresher, deeper and darker black.

passages.name: you stay lex go room
passages.text:
"Then I'm staying too," Becky said, though she sounded like my choice had very little to do with hers.

Lex paused, and looked over the both of us. "You can't. We have a life to start. What about college?

I licked my lips, trying to articulate my reasons when I realized. She wouldn't understand. She'd chosen to leave, so why would she ever understand my reasons for staying. The outside world still held appeal to her, after all. Becky might, but she was staying mum.

"It won't be forever," I said, and even that was a faint idea. Who knew how long I'd be here. Who knew.

Lex must have seen something in my face, in my stance, that showed that I wasn't about to move on this, and slumped. 

"I'll help you pack," I said, and we did. They needed to go before sunrise, and we all hurried [[OUT OF THE ROOM.|you stay lex go out room]]

destination.name: you stay lex go out room

passages.name: I guess
passages.text:
It made sense, as if his words were the outline to something I couldn't fully articulate, but there was still something off about it. Like an uncanny valley for deep thoughts. "…I guess," I said. He seemed much more confident about it as he kept going. "Sometimes, I think you just need to take a break, stay put and do nothing, just let the universe fill you back up." Above us, the Milky Way cut through the black like a river flowing nowhere. It looked like there were a million stars up there, more than plenty to fill anybody back up. "It's not really an option though." I said. "I mean, I'm traveling with my friends. We have a plan." Dean shrugged, "That's their problem. But who knows, they might need the break too. You can always ask them."
  • [["I think I will."|I think I will]]
  • [["…Maybe."|maybe][$go+=1]]

passages.name: don trap
passages.text:
"Be honest. Is this place a trap?" I asked, voice cracking. If it was, would I be okay asking? If it wasn't, would I be a fool for asking? Don Aquiles sighed. "You've been talking to 201, haven't you? Come sit." I sat, and he nodded. "This place, Maria Elena, is something special, a light in the dark, an oasis. But some people see a gift and only look for the hooks. Perhaps they have been hurt before, perhaps they are empty. "201, I will tell you, is empty. He tries to fill the hole inside himself with anything, any truth, but nothing is big enough to fill the hole inside of anybody. Not by itself. He'll see that one day. And then he'll leave. That's how it always goes." "…Do you really think he'll ever leave?" Where would something like The Jackalope even go? "That's not my question to ask, but I hope so. Motels aren't homes, Maria Elena. No matter how long you stay here."
[[➥|lobby]]

"How long have you been here?" "Too long," he said. "Too long, but I..." Here he paused, becoming rather distressed. "I-It's this place. I can't leave. I can't leave."

"It's a hotel with a magical neon flower, where time doesn't even work right — trust me, look at the clocks — and no one knows about it. You don't just let something like that slide." I wasn't sure I agreed, but I could see the glint in Lex's eye, that bulldog tenacity that helped her get ahead. Once she had the idea in her head, it was hard to shake her off.

passages.name: bs brochures
passages.text:
The brochures advertise a whole range of places, from diners to drive-ins. My personal favorite was whole column of ads for different mini-golf courses including death metal mini-golf, thematically-similar-but-legally-distinct Godzilla mini-golf, and French Revolution mini-golf. The tiny guillotine chopping balls in half was a nice touch. I took a few. Maybe I could convince Lex to make some detours.
[[➥|bs lobby]]

passages.name: tired
passages.text:
There's something soothing about the desert, a comfort in seeing something so massive and so old that it feels eternal, even if nothing ever is. And in every desert, there is an oasis. Neon lights cast a green glow on the horizon, rising like a premature dawn. As we got closer, we could see the shape resolve into a giant neon cactus. Below it, the words "CACTUS BLUE MOTEL" blazed before a background of dark desert sky.
[[➥|intro lot]]

passages.name: cactus bloom
passages.text:
Above a glowing neon cactus, sat a living creature of neon. I looked at it as closely as I could, but I couldn't find the structure, the duplicates, anything. The cactus bloom above it was just flowing, and growing, and shedding beautiful light onto the motel.\n\n
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: 109 second
passages.text:
I knocked on room 109 and he called for me to come in. Inside, the room wasn't what I'd expected. I'd thought he'd have something wild, all paper and madness, but this place was pristine. Bed made. No papers. Only The Man sitting at his typewriter, facing me. The TV remote was next to him, hastily and badly hidden. I could see from here the page was blank. "Oh, welcome back. Do you want to read some more pages? I don't have much, but well you can't rush art, you know?" He said, laughing nervously.
    <>

passages.name: what mean
passages.text:
"What do you mean by that?" I asked, and he jumped at the chance to explain. "LOOK!" He hopped over to the evidence wall, one antler tugging at a long red string. "See, the whole place is a trap. People check in, but they never check out!" I squinted over at the wall. There were newspapers, some of them older than me, and photos, but nothing that seemed decipherable. He must have noticed my confusion because he kept going. "Fine! I'll prove it to you!" "How?" I asked, but he was already convincing me just by having put the idea in my head. Pushing Daisies isn't that good. Lex could never give up on a schedule. "By showing you how trapped it is. You know phones don't work here. They don't want you reaching the outside world." His nose twitched, and he looked to the door, nervous that we'd be found. "But I still haven't tested the last one, the last phone. It's a pay phone, down east by the highway, still in the light of the motel. If I'm right, you could go out there, and it wouldn't let you call." "And if it does?" He already had me and he knew it. He seemed sure it wouldn't. I was less sure, about that, about anything. But now I had to check it out.
[[➥|f21]]

passages.name: room 207 ending
passages.text:
I walked back into room 207, ready to talk. The girls were both sitting up in their beds. They seemed to know it was time to make a choice too. "So," Lex said, once I'd sat down beside her. "We have to choose now. Before dawn." "I guess," said Becky. No one sounded excited about it. "I already made my choice," I said. For the first time, I chose first. <>"I'm staying." <>

passages.name: no I dont
passages.text:
"No, I don't," I said. I didn't want to go back home, watching all my friends trickle away. I didn't want to start anew at college, alone. I didn't want to go back. "Then we can wait," Becky said, putting a hand on mine. "It'll be okay." I took a deep breath and shook myself. No matter how tempting it was I still wanted to at least try and figure this place out. So I went back with what I had planned. "Well, I uh…heard that there was this phone booth, out in the desert. It's why I came actually. To get some quarters." Becky paused. "A phone booth?"
  • [["Yeah. Come with me?"|becky come with me][$becky+=1]]

links.text: "Yeah, but you can stay if you like."

passages.name: smoking woman 1
passages.text:
There was a woman sitting on the floor, legs dangling through the railings. Her room door was open, spilling jazz onto the hallway. She wore a slip, a string of pearls, and she was smoking. Oh sure, she had a cigarette in her hand, and a pack of Marlboros next to her. But that wasn't what I meant. She was actually smoking. Her face was shrouded in smoke. It curled up from below her chin, obscuring her features with a grey cloud. When she spoke, scattered embers lit up inside it. "Take a picture, it'll last longer." <><>
  • [["Uh… do you know your face is uh…."|sorry smoking]]
  • [["Well excuse me, I think there's reason to stare."|smoking excuse me]]

passages.name: aj 207
passages.text:
The TV was playing some kind of strange infomercial when I walked into the room. It seemed to be an infomercial for an DVD of infomercials. Collector's edition too. Becky sat lounging in the bed, enraptured. I admit, it was hard to look away. But somehow we managed. "No more Pushing Daisies?" I asked, taking a seat by her. They were doing a knife demonstration: one knife cutting a smaller, inferior knife. That was always my favorite. "Not yet. They said it'd come back on tomorrow, like a marathon, but this is fine too. I even changed it sooner so I didn't get spoiled. It's gonna be great." She leaned back, stretching out onto the sheets. She looked…good. Refreshed. "You gonna stick around? I think they might do the can slicing demo next." <>
  • [[Maybe for a bit.|maybe a bit]]
  • [[I just came to get some quarters.|quarters get]]

links.text: I just came to get some quarters.

passages.name: you go becky go out room
passages.text:
We walked fast, the sun already peeking past the dusty mesa in the distance, and piled everything into the car. Shutting the trunk, Lex walked up to me. "Not too late to change your mind," she said. I paused. I wondered, if I said something, would she ask me to stay with her. To stay by her side. But I didn't ask, and neither did she. Behind her, Dean frowned, disappointed. "I'll be okay." The sky was already turning pink by the time we drove off. Becky was driving. Behind us, I could see the cactus bloom, flicker one, twice, and fade. The motel went out of sight shortly after. I fixed my eyes on the highway, long and lonely. I turned Becky and let out a breath. I was about to tell her why I had wanted to stay. I had to do something, after all. There were still 750 miles left to Santa Monica.
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: maria elena
passages.text:
I hate the way my name sounds on American tongues. The a's move forward into the nose, the e's becomes sneers. My parents should have thought of this, of the fact that I was born in the US and would live in the US before they left me with a name I'd constantly have to correct people about. "It's Maria Elena," I said, voice tired and just so 300% done with everything. He just smiled, as if he wasn't listening and handed over a little plastic keychain, with bright white letters that read ROOM 207. "There's coffee here after five. Stairs are down the hall. Pool's closed for repairs." We nodded, and I could feel how tired we all were. It was time to rest.
[[➥|bs lobby]]

passages.name: down easy
passages.text:
I let him down easy. It wasn't that I was scared or anything, but he seemed kind of jumpy and those antlers looked pretty sharp. "I'm sure you had a great theory, but uh, well, the phone booth worked fine." I said. It cost money, of course, which may have been a little weird for here, but nonetheless. Its ears drooped down, slumping on its haunches as it turned back to the wall. "I could have sworn, but no… there's something else… I know it. I know it."
  • [[Just give it up.|give it up][$go+=1]]
  • [[Something else like what?|something like what]]

passages.name: you go both stay room
passages.text:
They looked at me like I'd just broken their hearts.

"But you said you'd wanted to stay," said Becky, almost in a whine. "You wanted to stay because…"

And her words died out, because she realized she had no idea why I wanted to stay. Neither of them did.

"It'll be fine. I'll come by on the drive back." If they were still here. If I could find it again. "I'll swing by and pick you up."

They didn't believe me. I barely did. But they helped me pack anyway, and we all, solemnly, [[LEFT THE ROOM.|you go both stay out room]]

passages.name: leave
passages.text:
"I need them to leave," I said, finally, and he stood up. He was only taller than me by about an inch, but it didn't matter. He had the upper hand here. "You're the one who wanted to stay in the first place. Isn't this what you wanted? A place to rest?" "Yes, but—" "But what?" He reached over to me, placing the keys in my hand as he held it. "Why do you have to go?"
  • [[I have to start college.|college]]
  • [[I have to go back to my family.|back to family]]

passages.name: some trap conceal
passages.text:
I let her stay there, for a moment, piecing herself together. She shook herself, as if ridding herself of a layer of dust and straightened. "Okay, let's just… let's just get out of here." She said. There was something there, right under the surface she wasn't saying. It felt like a riptide, invisible, and ready to dash me against the rocks. "Yeah," I agreed. "Let's just go." <>
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: not matter
passages.text:
"It wouldn't matter if I told her," I said, kicking a rock onto the highway. Lex was leaving. Becky was leaving. Everyone was leaving me behind, and soon, their opinions wouldn't matter anymore. "Of course it would matter," she said. "At the very least you could could have come out to us. I get it, it's hard, but we wouldn't have thought differently of you." I rolled my eyes. "Yeah, cause you're really proving that right now." Becky bristled. I felt it, like a current through our linked arms. "I'm not… Mari, this isn't like that. I don't care that you're a lesbian, and neither would Lex. But you never told us. You never tell us anything." "I'm not-" "Don't lie to my face, Mari," She broke away. We stopped walking, standing in the middle of the highway.
  • [[I felt panic creep up my throat. This was exactly what I wanted to avoid.|panic becky]]
  • [[I felt rage bubble under my skin. She just didn't understand.|rage becky]]
  • [[I felt tired. I could try to explain, but would it work?|tired becky]]

passages.text:
"I don't know," I said. "Oh you do, but you don't want to admit it." She blew out a puff of smoke from her puff of smoke. It looked pretty weird. "You should think about it though. It's pretty nice, and it's not like you need to pay for it." I stopped. "What?" "Yeah, no cost after night one. Or did you think we all had the cash to stick around?" I hadn't thought of it, but obviously she knew plenty about the motel. Maybe I should ask her stuff.

passages.name: you stay they go room
passages.text:
Becky paused, and shook her head. "I can't stay. I just can't. I need to go back out and talk to Aaron, to start school."

"Same, and you have to start too, Mari," said Lex. "Why do you want to stay?"

I licked my lips, trying to articulate my reasons when I realized. They wouldn't understand. They'd chosen to leave, so why would they ever understand my reasons for staying. The outside world still held appeal to them, after all. 

"It won't be forever," I said, and even that was a faint idea. Who knew how long I'd be here. Who knew.

They must have seen something in my face, in my stance, that showed that I wasn't about to move on this, and slumped. 

"I'll help you pack," I said, and we did. They needed to go before sunrise, and we all hurried [[OUT OF THE ROOM.|out room you stay they go]]

passages.name: season 2
passages.text:
"But it got cancelled after Season 2, right?" I said, half sure, half a question. "It was!" Becky said, tossing herself onto the bed and clutching the remote in glee. It was the most excited I'd seen her since she'd gotten her acceptance letter. "I don't really know how it works, but I'm not exactly going to complain." I peered over at the TV. Maybe they had more seasons of Veronica Ma— No, I had to focus. "Do you think we can convince Lex to stick around for an extra day or two, Mari? She left here as soon as the blue light came on, but I don't think she's seen this. We don't need to actually make it to California, right?" Becky clutched at my hands, desperate. "You should ask her. She never says no to you." "She always says no to me," I said. "She sometimes doesn't say no to you," Becky countered. Her eyes were bright. She wanted this. Badly.

passages.name: becky see what do
passages.text:
"I'll see what I can do," I said. I had very little confidence in anyone's ability to make Lex do anything. But I liked to pretend I had the influence on her that Becky thought I did. Becky smiled. "Great! She likes you better, anyway, and I'm pretty sure she's still mad that I ate the last BBQ chip yesterday." "She wouldn't hold a grudge like that," I said. Becky looked unimpressed. "Okay, well she wouldn't hold it this long." Another look. "Okay, that's beside the point. Besides, we have your reasons too." Becky smiled. It didn't reach her eyes. I had a flash, a moment when I realized I was her best friend, and I didn't know her at all. "Just, see what you can do, okay?" she asked.<> I heard a cart rumble in the hallway.<> "Alright, I'll see what I can do."

passages.name: out room all stay
passages.text:
The sun was barely peeking over the desert mesa in the distance, and the more it rose, the dimmer the floating, neon, cactus bloom became. We sat there, feet dangling off the railing, until the sky was tinted pink and every shade of blue was chased away. Then Becky yawned and stood. "Let's get some rest," she said. In the parking lot, I saw Dean wave at us. I knew I'd ask him more questions later. Maybe tomorrow night. Maybe night after next. After all, it wasn't like I was in any rush.

Then the rooms: 103: Vacant 102: Vacant 101: Vacant At the corner, the dimly lit [[STAIRS|bs f21]] and a sharp turn to [[ROOMS 104-110.|bs f12]] And out into the night, the almost empty [[PARKING LOT.|bs parklot]]

passages.name: not miners
passages.text:
"We're not miners," I said, but I could already tell I was going to get sucked into the undertow. It was inevitable. Lex was inevitable. "We can figure it out. There has to be some kind of equipment or information somewhere. I mean, they dug the tunnel, didn't they?" I didn't say that they'd probably left the gold in the ground for a reason. She wouldn't listen. Instead, Lex would stay in this tunnel searching. I could go explore the rest<>.<>, and try and find the jackalope's books while I was at it.<>

passages.name: lex motel 1

"So what do you think?" I asked, trying to feel her out. I'd known her long enough to read her, but I still wanted to be sure she wouldn't default back to our old itinerary. "It's amazing, isn't it? I don't know why it didn't come up in any of my research." "Probably because it's a magic motel," I teased. Lex rolled her eyes and nudged me. "Don't be facetious, you know what I mean. Still stuff like this…well, it just doesn't exist. Not for people like us." "People like us?" I asked. She nodded. "You know, ordinary people."

<>The highway stretched out east, back towards Houston and a phone booth we didn't see on the way. "Hey, not leaving without me, are you?" Becky said, coming down from the parking lot. Dean waved at her as she walked by. "No," I said. I had been. To be honest, I hadn't really expected her to come. But I'm glad she was here. She looped her arm in mine. Maybe I'd been a little transparent in my disbelief. "There, now let's go."
[[➥|phone walk]]
<>To the west: California, east: Houston. North: was the motel, and the desert sprawled out into the south. <>Somewhere down to the east, there was a phonebooth. But walking out in to the darkness alone, I wasn't sure. Besides, I'd probably need a quarter or something. Yeah, that was why I didn't go. I could get one from the room first.<>No one was coming down this dusty road. Especially, not me by myself.<>

passages.name: pk lobby
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Lobby

The motel office was an empty square room, cut in half by a long counter that separated manager from guest. Behind the cheap faux-wood counter, there a single door marked Private. Locked. On my side of the counter, there was a rack of brochures, folded and yellowed by wear and time, and a vending machine, turned off.
[[➥|pk f11]]

The voices got louder as I got closer, then died, and right as I was passing the door, it opened. The Man in Room 109 was tall, and white, and thin. His sweater had elbow patches. His glasses had tape. He looked startled to see me. "Oh. You're new, aren't you?" I'd barely nodded when he smiled. "Excellent! Could I please have a moment of your time? I'm working on a new manuscript, see, and I would love to get a fresh set of eyes." <><>
  • [["Sure."|109 yes]]
  • [["No thanks."|109 yes]]

passages.name: bs highway
passages.text:
The Highway

To the West: California. East: Houston. North was the motel, and the desert sprawled out into the South. But mostly it was dark. I wasn't about to wander off.
[[➥|bs parklot]]

passages.name: no but have to
passages.text:
"No, but I have to," I said. I didn't want to go back home, watching all my friends trickle away. I didn't want to start anew at college, alone. I didn't want to go back. But life didn't work that way. "Why? This place doesn't seem to follow rules, so why should we?" Becky's voice wavered, but I didn't know how to answer her. So I shrugged, and just didn't answer, not now. "Nevermind. I heard that there was this phone booth, out in the desert. It's why I came actually. To get some quarters." Becky paused. "A phone booth?"
  • [["Yeah. Come with me?"|becky come with me][$becky+=1]]

passages.name: parking lot
passages.text:
Downstairs, it was easier to see him as the relic of 1960's nostalgia that he is. All leather jackets, tight jeans, and a vintage bike. He had an easy smile, and I sat on the curb near his bike, looking up to the black sky. "Can't sleep?" He turned his head, blowing a puff of smoke away from me. Considerate, for a smoker. "I'm Dean, by the way." "Maria Elena, and yeah, I can't sleep either." I said. We'd met plenty of people on the road so far. I found a comfort in talking to strangers, in the knowledge that it will always be a temporary relationship. That whatever you say would be left in the desert with a boy who probably won't remember your name. "So what brings you out into this middle of nowhere, Miss Maria?" he asked.

"Well the lady upstairs plays some great jazz, and The Don has some bachata we like, but the rest of them don't really jam well. And never ask 109 for lyrics, he's just not very good. 201's never come to our shows either," said The Singer. A sudden cymbal, a crash, like lightning. "Oh yeah! And Dean. Now there's a groovy dude. He's always been great about coming to jams."

passages.name: becky keys
passages.text:
I walked back into the room. Becky was lying on the bed again, curled under the sheets. Lex was on the other bed, focusing hard on the vacuum sealer infomercial they were playing. "Hey, uh, are the car keys here?" I asked. Becky shrugged, not looking away from the screen. "You can check the bag." I did. They weren't there. "So?" Lex asked, as I started back towards the door. "Uh. I think I left them down in the parking lot." I had no such idea. I had no idea where they were. "I'll go look real quick." The girls let me go. They didn't say a word. I ran. I couldn't be the one who lost the keys. Could I?
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: 109 yes
passages.text:
Before I could answer, he just burst into a grin, as if I'd said yes. "Great! Just a second." He turned back into the room, rustling and came out with about 3 pages. They were type-written, on a real type-writer and still smelled like pen corrector and ink. "Well?"
…and the highway, black like the coffee in the diner where I'd met her, stretched out like a slip and slide made of asphalt…
Well, I'd read worse. But I'd read some really bad fan fiction. He didn't let me answer before he spoke again. "Oh, well, it's not finished." He said. "I still have a lot to write." "How much?" That he at least let me ask. He shrugged. "You can't put a number on art." Yeah… maybe it'd be best if I just asked him some questions.
    <>

passages.name: welcome to the party
passages.text:
"Welcome to the party," I said, voice dead and tired.

Becky took a step towards me, then another. I took one step back.

"Let's just find the phone booth, okay?" I felt tired, drained.

"…okay." She said. "Whatever you want, Mari. We have time to talk about it whenever we're ready."

She took another step forward. I let her. Her arm looped into mine and we began to walk, in sync, in the quiet.

We didn't say anything until we saw a streetlight that wasn't there before light up, revealing a [[PHONE BOOTH|phone booth becky]] that definitely hadn't been there before.

passages.name: tired becky
passages.text:
I felt tired. I could try to explain, but would it work? How could she understand me, coming from where she was. She'd had her perfect boyfriend her whole life, and this was only the first little hiccup. How could she understand? "I'm not lying. It's just complicated," I sighed. "This is exactly why I didn't tell you, you know. You'd want to know and dissect and I don't even understand it." "It's not hard, Mari!" Becky said, arms wide and angry. "Just say "Becky, I think I'm gay!" "But I'm not," I said softly "I don't know what I am. Bisexual, maybe, I don't know? Why does it even matter to you anyway?" "I'm your friend! I'm supposed to know this stuff!" She said. "Yeah, like I'm supposed to know about you and Aaron having problems?" "That's different," she muttered. I swallowed, shaking my head. "Why? Cause you're leaving? I don't need to know anymore cause you're leaving anyway? Is that it?!" "No!" Becky said, quickly. Too quickly? I don't know. "I just didn't want to think about it."
  • [[Welcome to the party.|welcome to the party]]
  • [[Well maybe you should.|maybe talk][$becky+=1]]

passages.name: revisit 3
passages.text:
I walked back into the room. Becky was lying on the bed again, curled under the sheets. Lex was on the other bed, focusing hard on the exercise chair infomercial they were playing. I thought about sitting back down, but I didn't have time for that. I had a Jackalope to talk to.
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: no more
passages.text:
"No! No more! I'm not gonna keep running around for you." I was done. "But you need to check, you need to know! This place is a trap!" "Just because you're to scared to leave, it doesn't make this place a trap!" I shouted. The Jackalope froze, deadly still, as if I'd morphed from human to predator. We both stood there, breathing, still, before he moved closer. "Yeah, then where are your car keys?" My hand went to my pocket, empty.
  • [[They're gone.|keys gone]]
  • [[I never had them.|never had them]]

passages.name: jack goodbye
passages.text:
<>I tried to get in, but he wouldn't open the door, even when I called out. "No! You've fallen for his tricks! Hell, you were probbaly Dean's spy all along! Go away!" "I wasn't!" I said. I'd make a terrible spy. "I hope you're happy with this, now GO AWAY!"
[[➥|pk f21]]
<>I knocked, but the door was locked now. "Don't...don't come in," he said, voice small and weak. "I'm leaving," I said. "You can do it, you know. Leave." "Maybe you can." He replied, and then didn't answer afer that. No matter how much I knocked.
[[➥|pk f21]]
<>

passages.name: never had them
passages.text:
"I never had them," I said, but my voice shook. Had I? I felt cold, for the first time since arriving in the desert. I tried to think logically. Had I taken them out of the room? Had I ever had them in the first place? I couldn't remember. He could see the panic in my face, and he relished in it. "Yeah, they're gone. Look, if you like, but I bet you won't find them. I bet you won't ever find them."
[[➥|f21]]

passages.name: maybe talk
passages.text:
"Well maybe you should," I snapped.

Becky looked away. "Isn't that the whole point of this place? That we can stay here away from all those things we don't want to do?"

I shrugged. It probably was, but it didn't make me feel any better. "Maybe. I don't know."

She took a step towards me. I let her. Her arm looped into mine and we began to walk, in sync, in the quiet.

We didn't say anything until we saw a streetlight that wasn't there before light up, revealing a [[PHONE BOOTH|phone booth becky]] that definitely hadn't been there before.

passages.name: shelves
passages.text:
On the shelves, there were thick leather-bound books, like the kind that Don Aquiles had been writing in. I opened one. Blank. Another was filled with squiggles and a rather good sketch of the thunderbird outside. The third, finally, had some names. Tanya Cohen (8/1/14 - 8/3/14), Brian Nichols(9/23/14-9/25/14), Chloe Harper (10/30/14 - 11/30/14), Pat Torres (11/31/14 - 12/2/14). Normal names, normal dates. Normal people who came here and left. <>
[[➥|third fork]]

passages.name: 109 question done
passages.text:
I was done asking him questions. "Oh, yes, well, so much more to write! Do knock any time, you can read my latest drafts!" I nodded and walked away quickly.
[[➥|f12]]

passages.name: just ask
passages.text:
"I could just ask," I said and he jumped close immediately. "No! He'll catch on to us. Don't ask him and DEFINITELY don't ask Dean!!" I backed away. I really wished he'd blink. "Why not Dean?" "Well because he's the mastermind behind this whole thing!" "And the Don?" "Just a cover," he sighed, as if I was being particularly stupid. "Just don't tell them." I wasn't going to argue with him, not now. But it seemed like he had a theory for everything.
  • [[What shed?|what shed]]
  • [[What am I looking for?|looking]]
  • [[I'm ready.|im ready]]

passages.text:
Lex was frowning as she looked down the darkened hallway at the first fork. "Hey, is something wrong?" I said, stepping closer. Had Don Aquiles done something? Had she discovered something that would prove the jackalope's theory right? She looked over at me, eyes wide for a moment, before her face smoothed out and she smiled. "Mari! What are you doing here?" She smiled, as if the frown before had never been there. "Looking for some of the record books," I said. "Oh, what for?"

"The Smoking Woman, in 210," I let it trail off. "Oh, she's great. We smoke together sometimes, on that one night it rains and we can't go out into the parking lot. You know she's a divorcee? Ditched her asshole husband and went to start a new life in California as an actress." I tried to imagine what she looked like under the smoke, if she was someone I could have seen in movies. Dean seemed to notice and just nodded. "Yeah, she was a looker for a while, but she feels better like that. Also, you know Smoking Woman isn't her name?" Oops. "What is it?" Dean shrugged. "Hell if I know."

passages.name: logic
passages.text:
But I knew I could use logic to convince her. She wanted to study physics, after all, and science was nothing but facts. Fact: We were tired. Fact: We could use the break. Fact: Becky was already standing, ready to open the door when I was. "Mari! Come in, you won't believe this," she said, yanking me inside of the room. It looked exactly the same as before. Same painting of red rock mesa. Same weird colored motel comforter. Same ancient blocky TV, only now it was on. "Look!" Becky pointed at the screen. Kristin Chenoweth was running around a colorful pie shop. "Nice," I said. "I didn't know they were playing reruns of Pushing Daisies." Becky shook her head. "They aren't. It's Season 3." I stopped, and looked back at the screen.
  • [["But it got cancelled after Season 2."|season 2][$becky+=1]]

It never failed to get my blood pumping. She never failed to make me feel alive. We ended up agreeing that Lex would stay in this tunnel searching. I could go explore the rest<>.<>, and try and find the jackalope's books while I was at it.<>

passages.name: beautiful
passages.text:
"It's beautiful," I said, and it was. This desert had been an endless plain of nothingness, and here, where I thought there'd been maximum nothing, was something magical, something amazing. You'd never find something like this in Houston. I'm relatively sure you couldn't find something like this anywhere. Dean smiled, wild and careless, coming alive under the lights just as much as the rest of this place. "It's always this great. No matter how many times I've seen it." "How many times have you seen it?" I asked. "Gosh, I dunno. I think I've lost count by now." He laughed, bright and joyful. In the hallway across from us, lights began to come on inside motel rooms, guests beginning to awaken. "But it never gets old, you never get tired of it. That's the beauty of this place: you never get tired." He stood up then, dusting the road off his jeans and reaching up towards the night sky in a single, sinuous stretch. "You should look around and make the most of it. See if you can't convince your friends to stay now."
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: you go lex go out room
passages.text:
We walked fast, the sun already peeking past the dusty mesa in the distance, and piled everything into the car. Shutting the trunk, Becky walked up to me. "It's not too late. Stay with me?" She said, small, and scared and alone. But Lex was standing off to the side, ready to climb into the driver's side. She was lit up by the sunrise and I knew I couldn't make any other choice. "Sorry, I'll call? I mean, I found the phone booth." I tried to joke. Becky just nodded, resigned, and stepped back. The sky was already turning pink by the time we drove off. Behind us, I could see the cactus bloom, flicker one, twice, and fade. The motel went out of sight shortly after. I fixed my eyes on the highway, long and lonely. I turned Lex and let out a breath. I was about to tell her why I had wanted to stay. I had to do something, after all. There were still 750 miles left to Santa Monica.
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: you stay lex go out room
passages.text:
We walked fast, the sun already peeking past the dusty mesa in the distance, and piled everything into the car. Shutting the trunk, Lex walked up to me. "Not too late to change your mind," she said. I paused. I wondered, if I said something, would she ask me to go with her. To stay by her side. But a movement distracted me. It was Dean, waving and smiling. I smiled back. "Nah, I'll be okay." The sky was already turning pink by the time she drove off. I walked slowly and sat next to Dean on the curb. Above us, the cactus bloom was flickering, neon dying in the dawn light. "You're gonna love it here. You and Becky. I promise," he said, wrapping an arm around my shoulder. He smelled like leather, and smoke and I nodded. "Yeah, you know what… I think we will."
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: bs 207
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Room 207

The smell of industrial strength detergent. A poorly done painting of red rock mesas. It was a shitty room exactly the same as a million other shitty rooms, in a million other nowheres. But that didn't make the two queen beds look any less inviting. Lex had already dropped her duffle in front of the bed to the right, brushed her teeth and changed into her sleep shirt. Becky was on the other bed, still on her phone and frowning. "You know they don't even have WiFi here?" she said. "What kind of hotel doesn't have WiFi?"
  • [["At least it has AC."|ac]]
  • [["Hotel is being a little generous, don't you think?"|hotel generous]]

links.text: "Hotel is being a little generous, don't you think?"

passages.name: ask Don aquiles
passages.text:
"You could ask Don Aquiles," I suggested. I knew the truth, but I didn't want to be the one to tell her. I didn't want to be the one who stole her good mood away. But her good mood left anyway. Lex let out a soft sigh, running her fingers over the golden stone. "Shame, I… I honestly thought…"
  • [[What did you think?|what did you think][$lex+=1]]
  • [[Let's not. Let's not think about this anymore.|lets not think]]

links.text: Let's not. Let's not think about this anymore.

passages.name: obvdoes
passages.text:
"Well it obviously does." No matter how much my mind wanted to deny it, the reality of it was here, bright as neon. This place was just ever so slightly skewed, like a real motel seen through a fun-house mirror. "Still… we must be here for a reason." She said, leaning back on the counter. "Maybe the universe just figured we needed a break?" I know I did. Lex looked away, out towards the parking lot and the clear night sky. She looked tired. The trip had run her down as well, I guessed. "Yeah, maybe it did."
    <>

    • <> <>
  • [[I asked about Becky.|lex becky 1]]
    • <>
  • [[I left her to keep exploring.|leave Lex]]

links.text: I asked her what she thought about Don Aquiles.
I left her to keep exploring.

passages.name: dont crush
passages.text:
"I said I don't have a crush on Lex," I repeated, cheeks hot. Becky kept going. Seemed like she'd gathered enough steam to just plow through any objections I had. "I'm not stupid, Mari. To be honest, I just wished you'd trusted us enough to at the very least come out to us." There it was, the sting of guilt. Becky was good at that, finding a weak point and lasering in. Especially when she was on the defensive herself. "It isn't like that…" "Isn't it? I mean, I get it, it's hard, but we wouldn't have thought differently of you." I rolled my eyes. "Yeah, cause you're really proving that right now." Becky bristled. I felt it, like a current through our linked arms. "I'm not… Mari, this isn't like that. I don't care that you're a lesbian, and neither would Lex. But you never told us. You never tell us anything." "I'm not-" "Don't lie to my face, Mari," She broke away. We stopped walking, standing in the middle of the highway.
  • [[I felt panic creep up my throat. This was exactly what I wanted to avoid.|panic becky]]

passages.name: Aaron
passages.text:
"We could call Aaron," I said. "We can't," said Becky. "It's too late." I looked at her, eyebrow raised. This was the girl who almost scheduled her 1am calls to her boyfriends. "It's complicated, all right?" Becky said, her arm tightening around mine. "Things have been…rough." "Things were fine in the car," I said. Things had been fine this whole trip. "Heh," she breathed out. "Things haven't been fine since we got our acceptance letters. I don't know what's coming next. But whatever it is, it… well it probably wouldn't help to wake him up." Becky and Aaron had seemed solid, like the asphalt under our feet. It'd been a fact since freshman year. It wasn't even my relationship, but it still felt like another loss. "I'm sure it'll work out. You guys gave been together forever. I'm sure if you just talk about it-" Which was exactly the wrong thing to say. "Talk? That can't always fix things." Becky scoffed. "Besides, that's funny coming from you."
  • [[What's that supposed to mean?|supposed to mean][$becky+=1]]
  • [[This isn't about me.|about me]]

"What do you think of the other guests?" She twitched her fingers, dropping ash down onto the floor. "The Band downstairs plays shitty music, but Dean's some nice eye candy when he comes out to the lot." She waved at him down in the parking lot. He raised his cigarette in greeting. "The guy in Room 109 is pretentious, but a harmless idiot really. Never met the guest in 201. They keep to themselves mostly." Another tap, more ash. "Then again, so do I."

passages.name: dean trap
passages.text:
"Hey, Dean," I said, sitting down next to him. "Do you think this place is a trap?" "Nah. The universe doesn't care that much," he said. "I know what a trap looks like and this… this isn't even temptation. Frankly, if that's what it was going for it should be ashamed of itself." "Well we want to stay," I said. "Doesn't that count for something?" "Not really," he said. "Is the beach a trap if you want to stay there? Is the forest? Some things just are."
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: me drive
passages.text:
I was driving. It was my turn, and while I wasn't crazy about it, I wasn't going to be the one who didn't pull my weight. Still, the road was straight and empty and there wasn't much to do but think. About where you were going. About where we'd been. Neither of those appealed. Maybe if we had some better music… "Is it cool if we change the music? I think this is our 3rd Hamilton in two days," I said.
  • [[Becky changed the music.|becky music]]

passages.name: about me
passages.text:
"This isn't about me," I said. "This is about you and Aaron." "Suuure," she said. "Like you have a lot of experience talking about relationships." I tightened my hand on her arm. "Just cause I haven't had a boyfriend-" She laughed. "What? What are you talking about?!" "Mari, we all know about your crush on Lex." "I don't have a crush on Lex," I lied. It was a comfortable one, well formed and well suited to my tongue. Becky went on as if she hadn't listened to me. "She doesn't know, of course, but really you aren't one to bring up talking about feelings when you can't even tell Lex how you feel."
  • [[I said I don't have a crush on Lex.|dont crush]]

"I just came to get some quarters," I said, even though the temptation of the infomercial was strong. It was so tempting, to just sit with Becky like we had before. Like we might never do again. "Getting something from the vending machine? I could use a soda." Becky said. I shook my head. "A phone booth actually. Supposedly there's one out in the middle of the desert." "Really?"

passages.name: use the break
passages.text:
But I knew she could use the break too. The last few months had been a rush of arrangements, of calls to housing and financial affairs, of a thousand forms. She and Lex has gotten it extra bad since they were both heading so far away. Surely they'd want a break. She was standing and reaching for the door when I opened it. "Mari! Come in, you won't believe this," she said, yanking me inside of the room. It looked exactly the same as before. Same painting of red rock mesa. Same weird colored motel comforter. Same ancient blocky TV, only now it was on. "Look!" Becky pointed at the screen. Kristin Chenoweth was running around a colorful pie shop. "Nice," I said. "I didn't know they were playing reruns of Pushing Daisies." Becky shook her head. "They aren't. It's Season 3." I stopped, and looked back at the screen.
  • [["But it got cancelled after Season 2."|season 2]]
  • [[Well… Becky is the one who owns the DVDs. Guess I was wrong.|own the dvd][$becky+=1]]

links.text: Well… Becky is the one who owns the DVDs. Guess I was wrong.

passages.name: motel band
passages.text:
"What do you think of the motel?" Here, for the first time, there was dissonance. An angry riff from The Guitarist. Glee from the bass. Silence on the drums. "It's…well…it's better than touring." The Singer said. "We needed the time to work on our next record though." "And how's that going?" Silence from The Band.

passages.name: lets not think
passages.text:
"Let's not," I said, feeling tired and just so done with this bunker, with this moment. Dean had promised me I'd never feel tired in this place. Goes to show. "Let's not think about this anymore." Things would be fine if we could just leave. If we could just go back upstairs and pretend that everything was fine. Everything looked better under the blue light of the cactus bloom. "Come on…" I said, but Lex shook her head, turning away from me. "It just sucks. This whole thing just sucks!" Her shout echoed in the hallway. "I should have known that even the gold in this place would be fake." She sighed, long and low. "Some trap." <3>>

The Cactus Blue Motel - Pool

The pool was half empty now. The water was still a brilliant blue under the cactus bloom. But everything else was faded. Towels gone. Chlorine smell too strong. Out by the desert, the sky was lightening. The stars were fading.

passages.name: I get that
passages.text:
I thought about the applications, about the mad rush to get into the right school, to prepare the right future, and felt exhausted at the memory alone and nodded. "Yeah, I get that." "Sometimes, I think you just need to take a break. Stay put and do nothing, just let the universe fill you back up." Above us, the Milky Way cut through the black like a river flowing nowhere. It looked like there were a million stars up there, more than plenty to fill anybody back up. "It's not really an option though," I said. "I mean, I'm traveling with my friends. We have a plan." Dean shrugged, "That's their problem. But who knows, they might need the break too. You can always ask them."
  • [["I think I will."|I think I will]]
  • [["…Maybe."|maybe][$go+=1]]

passages.name: intro lot
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Parking Lot

We pulled in to the parking lot, empty except for a beat up sedan that looked like it hadn't moved in decades. "Are you sure about this place?" I asked Lex. "I'm sure we shouldn't keep driving much longer," said Lex. "We're still on schedule. We'll just get up early, pick up breakfast on the road, and we'll still make it to Meteor Crater before it's too late." Becky rolled her eyes, even as she unbuckled her seat belt. "Yeah, we wouldn't want to be late for the meteors. The rocks won't care if we sleep in."
  • [["Let's just try and get what rest we can before we go."|get some rest]]

passages.name: lobby
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Lobby

The motel office was an empty square room, cut in half by a long counter that separated manager from guest. Behind the cheap faux-wood counter, there was a single door marked <>[[PRIVATE.|don aquiles]] It was slightly open.<>[[PRIVATE.|managers office]]<> On my side of the counter, there was a rack of [[BROCHURES|brochures]], folded and yellowed by wear and time, and a [[VENDING MACHINE|vending machine]], turned off. <> Lex was somewhere else, exploring. <> There was a door leading out to the [[PARKING LOT|parklot]], lit up by a red VACANCY SIGN, and another out to the [[FIRST FLOOR ROOMS|f11]].

passages.name: don guests
passages.text:
"What do you think of the guests?" "Oh, good people, good people. Just tired people you know. Well, then there's 201. He's a bit… odd, but still, good people. This isn't the kind of place where criminals come to rest. It's meant to be a good place." He seemed very sure about that.

links.text: "How long have you been working here?"

passages.name: just nodded
passages.text:
I hate the way my name sounds on American tongues. The a's move forward into the nose, the e's becomes sneers. My parents should have thought of this, of the fact that I was born in the US and would live in the US before they left me with a name I'd constantly have to correct people about. But I didn't correct him. I was just too tired for it. He handed over a little plastic keychain, with bright white letters that read ROOM 207. "There's coffee here after five. Stairs are down the hall. Pool's closed for repairs." We nodded, and I could feel how tired we all were. It was time to rest.
[[➥|bs lobby]]

passages.name: work that way
passages.text:
"It doesn't work that way, Becky." I said. "We can't just put the world on pause and stay here forever." "Why not?" She said, pushing away. "There's a woman on the balcony whose face is literally smoke. This place doesn't follow any rules. Why can't we just stay here?" "But what about Stanford?" This didn't make sense. She was the smartest out of the three of us. She was going to go off and be a scientist. She was going to change the world. "What about Stanford?" Becky said. "It can wait. We can wait. We could even take a gap year or something, just stay here. I mean, do you really want to go back to Houston?"
  • [[No I don't.|no I dont]]
  • [[No, but I have to.|no but have to][$go+=1]]

The Cactus Blue Motel - First Floor, Lobby and Rooms 101-103

Dim lights with a blue undertone lit up the first floor walkway. A thin corridor cut between the main building and the [[MOTEL LOBBY|pk lobby]]. A paper sign, curling at the edges read [[POOL|pk pool]], pointing towards the sound of burbling water. Then the rooms: 103: The music is dying down.
