passages.name: about the game
passages.text:
about the game

Released during IF Comp 2016

Click each link to reveal the section.

<>

Spoiler Free Blurb

Somewhere between New Mexico and Arizona, three friends were driving through a barren desert of red rocks, and wide empty skies. It was the end of summer, the end of high school, the end of so many things. And then they found the Cactus Blue Motel. <> <>

Content Warnings

Game includes some cursing, and discussions of existential ennui.<> <>

Game Length Estimates

The game averages about 40-60 minutes for the first play through.<>
[[➥|Start]]

passages.name: revisit 2
passages.text:
Becky lay on the bed. The TV was on, a Slap Chop. She didn't look over when I opened the door. Or when I closed it.
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: you go becky go room
passages.text:
Lex looked at me in shock, but Becky, she looked guilty.

"Me too," she said.

"But you said you'd wanted to stay," said Lex, trying to make sense of it. "You wanted to not have to talk to Aaron. And Mari, you wanted to stay because…"

And her words died out, because she realized she had no idea why I wanted to stay. 

"It'll be fine. We'll come by on the drive back." If they were still here. If we could find it again. "We'll swing by and pick you up."

Lex didn't believe me. I barely did. But she helped us pack anyway, and we all, solemnly, [[LEFT THE ROOM.|you go becky go out room]]

destination.name: you go becky go out room

passages.name: becky bed
passages.text:
I went to bed next to Becky. It was better this way. I just always had a hard time sleeping next to Lex. She fell asleep so fast. Meanwhile, I was stuck next to her, spinning around in my own brain. Sleeping next to Lex always felt lonelier than sleeping alone. Then again, Becky drifted off pretty quickly tonight, so this wasn't much better.
[[➥|insomnia]]

passages.name: all stay ending
passages.text:
"Then I'm staying too," said Becky, though she sounded like my choice had very little to do with hers.

Lex paused, and looked over the both of us. "I suppose, we all arrived together. We should all stay together."

Becky grinned, and hopped over to our bed, pulling us into a hug. I breathed into it, pure and clean. We could do this together, I realized. Rest what we needed, and then leave when we had to.

"Let's head outside to watch the sunrise," Becky said. Lex didn't argue and we all walked [[OUT OF THE ROOM.|out room all stay]]

passages.name: trip answer
passages.text:
"Me and some friends are taking a road trip out to California," I said. He smiled. "You too? That's cool. I've been heading west for a while. Sometimes it seems like you can never get out of the desert." I chuckled. Anyone who's ever had the misfortune of driving through Texas knows what he's talking about. "Still," he continued. "This ain't a bad place to stop." He leaned back on the motorcycle, gazing out past the parking lot and onto the highway. "I'd been driving for so long. Thinkin' of just staying here for a while, you know?" "And never make it to California?" I said. "I'll make it someday. Just…" He took a long drag of his cigarette before dropping the spent butt and grinding it under his boot. "You ever get tired of moving forward all the time. Like your soul is running out of gas?"
  • [["Yeah, I get that."|I get that]]
  • [["…I guess."|I guess][$go+=1]]

passages.name: back to becky
passages.text:
"I need to give them back to Becky." I said, hand still out. "Try again." Dean said. "She doesn't want to leave. She'd rather stay here than have to decide if she breaks up with her boyfriend. And she's right. That conversation would suck."
  • [[Lex will be mad if we mess with the schedule.|lex mad]]

links.text: Lex will be mad if we mess with the schedule.

passages.name: office shed
passages.text:
"Maria Elena, todo bien?" "Yeah, everything's fine. Have you seen Lex?" I answered in english. No matter how familiar I was with the language, how I was basically weaned on spanish lullabies and corazon de arepa, I still preferred the steadiness of english, of the language I used to communicate to all my friends. It always made me feel like a traitor. "If you're looking for your friend, she's running an errand for me out by the shed," he said helpfully.
  • [["Thanks. I'll go join her.|join her]]

passages.name: arriving at lobby
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Lobby

The lobby was an empty square room, cut in half by a long counter that separated manager from guest. Behind the cheap faux-wood counter, there was a single door marked PRIVATE. Back on my side, there was a rack of brochures, folded and yellowed by wear and time, and a vending machine, turned off. To the left, an open door led to the rest of the motel. Becky walked up to the brochures, riffling through them with vague interest. "Hey Mari, take a look at these." I glanced over, curious. Lex rolled her eyes, and moved up to the counter, where an older man stood, pale and utterly forgettable. "You girls need somethin'?" "Yes," Lex said, stepping up. "We need a room for the night. What are your rates?" Lex was best at handling logistics, but as the oldest, I was the one that actually got the room. I slid my ID across the counter and he grinned. "Mary Ellen. Cute name."
  • [["It's Maria Elena."|maria elena][$go+=1]]

passages.name: panic becky
passages.text:
I felt panic creep up my throat. This was exactly what I wanted to avoid. The confrontation, the anger, the accusation of lies. As if I had some obligation of telling her anything, let alone doing it now. Was this what friendship was supposed to be? Carving a place for yourself in someone else by hollowing out their secrets? I didn't know. I didn't know anything. "I-I'm not lying, I swear. It's just complicated," I struggled through the words. "This is exactly why I didn't tell you. You'd want to know and dissect and I don't even understand it." "It's not hard, Mari!" Becky said, arms wide and angry. "Just say "Becky, I think I'm gay!"" "But I'm not!" I shouted, feeling heat rise up, as if the asphalt was giving it off and fueling my panic. "I don't know what I am! Bisexual, maybe, I don't know. Why does it even matter to you anyway?!" "I'm your friend! I'm supposed to know this stuff!" She said. "Yeah, like I'm supposed to know about you and Aaron having problems?" "That's different," she muttered. I swallowed, shaking my head. "Why? Cause you're leaving? I don't need to know anymore cause you're leaving anyway? Is that it?!" "No!" Becky said, quickly. Too quickly? I don't know. "I just didn't want to think about it."
  • [[Welcome to the party.|welcome to the party]]
  • [[Well maybe you should.|maybe talk][$becky+=1]]

passages.name: supposed to mean
passages.text:
"What's that supposed to mean?" I said. Becky looked out into the desert. "Well, you're not exactly great at talking about relationships, you know." I tightened my hand on her arm. "Just cause I haven't had a boyfriend-" She laughed. "What? What are you talking about?!" "Mari, we all know about your crush on Lex." "I don't have a crush on Lex," I lied. It was a comfortable one, well formed and well suited to my tongue. Becky went on as if she hadn't listened to me. "She doesn't know, of course, but really you aren't one to bring up talking about feelings when you can't even tell Lex how you feel."
  • [[I said I don't have a crush on Lex.|dont crush]]
  • [[It wouldn't matter if I told her.|not matter][$becky+=1]]
  • [[What's going on between me and Lex has nothing to do with this.|nothing to do with this]]

links.text: I said I don't have a crush on Lex.
It wouldn't matter if I told her.
What's going on between me and Lex has nothing to do with this.

passages.name: third fork
passages.text:
I turned the corner, following the lights down a carved stone hallway. It opened up into a room. The size of the room felt… strange. The way the hallway had curved, the way the lights had shone, I had expected a sweeping ceiling, a giant cavern of a room.

Instead the room was normal sized, and perfectly unnerving because of it. 

Inside this perfectly normal room were sets of perfectly normal [[SHELVES|shelves]], a perfectly abnormal [[DOOR|tunnel door]] in the back.

Or I could go [[BACK TO THE MAIN TUNNEL|forward]].

passages.name: jack keys
passages.text:
I slammed the door open. "You were wrong." The Jackalope jumped, ran onto the bed, ran off the bed, ran under the bed, then in front of me. "What?!" "You heard me," I said. "You were wrong. There was nothing weird about those books. Nothing that showed anything like what you said." That's twice now. Twice he'd fooled me. I felt like an idiot. He shivered, as if with fear. "Then they've covered their tracks better than I thought! But I have one more piece of evidence!" <>
  • [[No! No more!|no more][$go+=1]]
  • [[What now?|what now]]

passages.name: pk f12
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - First Floor, Rooms 104-110

The cars in the[[PARKING LOT|pk parklot]] looked older. The rooms were quieter: 110: Vacant 109: A hushed television. No typing. Never typing. 108: Vacant 107: Vacant 106: Vacant 105: Vacant 104: Vacant The way [[UPSTAIRS|pk f21]] was still lit, barely. The light by the [[OTHER ROOMS(101-103)|pk f11]] also seemed to be fading.

passages.name: dean keys
passages.text:
Dean tossed Becky's keys into the air. In the light of the cactus bloom, they glimmered like falling stars. "Dean…" "Miss Maria. More questions?" He smiled, so easily, as if there was nothing wrong in world. "Uh, no, but those are my keys." I held my hand out. He kept smiling, tossing the keys in the air again. "They're Becky's keys. She dropped them earlier. Still, not sure what you need them for."
  • [[I need to give them back to Becky.|back to becky]]

links.text: I need to give them back to Becky.

passages.name: becky 1
passages.text:
<>I could start with Becky. <>I had been friends with Becky forever. Our moms worked together, and we lived near enough that there are embarrassing pictures of the two of us reaching back to when we were in diapers. We started school together, paired up in class, cried in each other's bedrooms. But despite all that, Becky always managed to throw me for a loop. I hadn't seen it coming when she dyed her hair blue. I never expected the way she threw herself into the AP science classes. I knew Becky, sure, but I never held the illusion that I could predict Becky. <>
  • [[But I knew I could use logic.|logic]]
  • [[But I knew she'd listen to me.|listen to me]]
  • [[But I knew she could use the break too.|use the break][$becky +=1]]

links.text: But I knew I could use logic.
But I knew she'd listen to me.
But I knew she could use the break too.

passages.name: get some rest
passages.text:
"Let's just try and get what rest while we can before we go." I said, as we stepped out of the car. I looked up at the motel sign again. We'd seen several like it on our trip here. Googie architecture, it was called. Swooping lines and visions of yesterday's future.

This one was a little more boring than most. The sign didn't even seem to be animated.

Still, all we needed was a place to stay. We took our bags, and walked into the [[MOTEL OFFICE|arriving at lobby]].

passages.name: bs beckys car
passages.text:
Becky's trusty silver Corolla was now Becky's trusty brown Corolla. Whatever, we'd all pitch in for a car wash once we got back to Houston.\n\n
[[➥|bs parklot]]

passages.name: 109 trap
passages.text:
He looked at me, and shook his head over and over again. "Trap? No, this place is a blessing! How else would I have the time to finish my novel?" "How much have you gotten done here?" I had to ask. I didn't see anything but the three pages he'd shoved at me. "Plenty! Three pages is plenty!" He said defensively. "I'll finish it soon, just you see. It'll be the next Great American Novel! Just you wait!" Yeah, even if I ended up staying. I didn't think I'd stay to read that. But then again, with the panic in his tone, I'm pretty sure he'd never finish.
[[➥|f12]]

passages.name: not really
passages.text:
"Not really," I said lamely. I'd played the flute badly in band. "No Problem! Over here," She shuffled me towards the instruments and handed me a guitar. "I didn't play the gui—" She didn't let me finish as she grabbed my shoulders. "Doesn't matter. We just want your new sound, fresh, you know!" She was beaming. The Drummer counted down with his sticks. I could almost hear it in my head: FIVE, SIX, SEVEN, EIGHT! And we played. Even me. The sound just seemed to spill from the guitar, amateurish, sure, but still recognizable. I couldn't say now, what kind of song we played, only that there was music, and fury, and the thunder of cymbals. Lex would have been impressed. In the end, we all flopped down, grinning. The Singer smiled. "Nice. You added some great sound. Will you be stickin' around to jam with us some more?
  • [["Yeah, probably."|yes band]]
  • [["Don't think so."|no band][$go +=1]]
  • [["What just happened?"|happened band]]

passages.name: phone walk
passages.text:
So we walked out into the desert, staying on the uneven gravel by the side of the road. She kept looking back at the motel. Not forward to wherever the phone booth might be, but back, towards the bright blue neon that still managed to light up our path. "Is everything okay?" I asked. She shrugged. "Just…not sure about this. Why are you heading out here anyway? What good would it do to call anyone?" I tried to tangle with the answer. I wasn't sure, about this, about anything. But I wanted to be sure. I wanted to be sure about something, so I might as well try to be sure about this. "I just want to know if it works. I mean, aren't you worried about this place? What if we're stuck here?" I asked. Becky shrugged. "I dunno. Who would we even call anyway?" <>
  • [[My parents.|my parents]]
  • [[911|911]]
  • [[Aaron.|Aaron]]
  • [[I don't know.|dont know call]]

passages.name: yes website
passages.text:
When Lex was alive like this, brimming with energy and ideas, it was always so easy to agree with her. "Yeah, that could really bring in business." I said. "Exactly," She said. "It's a magical motel and half the rooms are empty. Do you know how nuts that is? Just the fact that this place exists should enough to bring in loads of people." "And you'll be the one to bring them." "Well," she smiled. "that's just details, isn't it?"
    <>
  • [[I asked what she thought about the motel.|lex motel 1]]
    • <> <>
  • [[I asked about Becky.|lex becky 1]]
    • <>
  • [[I left her to keep exploring.|leave Lex]]

links.text: I asked what she thought about the motel.
I left her to keep exploring.

passages.name: of course worked
passages.text:
"Of course it worked!" I said, upset at the wild goose chase he'd sent me on. He jumped back startled, before turning back to the wall. "I could have sworn, but no… there's something else… I know it. I know it."
  • [[Just give it up.|give it up][$go+=1]]
  • [[Something else like what?|something like what]]

passages.name: yeah guess not trap
passages.text:
"Yeah," I said, even though I wasn't sure. "I guess not." "Exactly," she said, and nodded as if that was that. "Besides, if this place was a trap it'd be different. It'd be…wonderful, not just weirdly average." "Still…Wouldn't it be safer just to check, to look around?" I said. Was it so bad that I just wanted to be sure? "Alright," she said, giving in for once."I'm going down this way. We'll cover more ground like that." She said, and wandered off ahead towards some of the further branches.
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: lex aquiles 1
passages.text:
"So, what do you think of Don Aquiles?" She'd spent some time in the office with him, obviously. "He's nice, but a bit stuck behind the times," She said. "I think he needs someone to freshen up the place, bring it into the 21st century. You know he doesn't even have a website?"
  • [[I don't think it needs a website.|dont website][$lex+=1]]
  • [[Yeah, that could really bring in business.|yes website]]

links.text: I don't think it needs a website.
Yeah, that could really bring in business.

passages.name: f12
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - First Floor, Rooms 104-110

New cars filled the [[PARKING LOT.|parklot]] New life filled the rooms: 110: Vacant [[109: VOICES, BUT FROM A TV. THEY JUST DIDN'T SOUND REAL.|109]] 108: Vacant 107: Vacant 106: Vacant 105: Vacant 104: Vacant The way [[UPSTAIRS|f21]] was now brightly lit, and welcoming. The [[OTHER ROOMS (101-103)|f11]] on this floor were also ripe for exploration.

links.text: 109: VOICES, BUT FROM A TV. THEY JUST DIDN'T SOUND REAL.

passages.name: take smoke
passages.text:
I took the cigarette. She lit it, and I took a tentative drag. It went down, smooth and easy, even though I'd never done it before. My mom would kill me if she saw me now. The Smoking Woman seemed pleased, as she turned back out into the night. "A trap, you say? Heh, maybe. It certainly snagged us, but you don't have to offer people the world to tempt them. They'll sell their souls for a lot less. A quiet night. A pack of smokes." She took a long, long drag. "Some people don't want to leave the cage though, you gotta remember that too." "Do you?" This time I knew she was looking at me. Her whole body turned, and she shook her head. "Does it look like the world has anything left for me?"
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: f11
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - First Floor, Lobby and Rooms 101-103

Bright lights with a blue undertone lit up the first floor walkway. A thin corridor cut between the main building and the [[MOTEL LOBBY|lobby]] A printed paper sign, crisp white read [[POOL|pool]], pointing towards the sound of burbling water. Then the rooms: [[103: MUSIC, LOUD BUT INDISTINGUISHABLE.|the band]] 102: Vacant 101: A glow, cherry-red, through shuttered windows. At the corner, the [[STAIRS|f21]] and a sharp turn to [[ROOMS 104-110.|f12]] And out into the night, the [[PARKING LOT.|parklot]]

passages.name: houston get away
passages.text:
"Just trying to get away from Houston," I said. He laughed, smoke pushed from his mouth by the sound in a small puff. "What's so bad about Houston?" "Nothing…" I said, kicking a rock by the curb. "There's nothing bad about Houston, just nothing that great about it either." "Well I guess it's pretty good you got out of there, isn't it?" he said. It didn't always feel like that, especially not on long nights like this one. "I guess I expected a little more out of this trip." "Yeah, I get that. There's only so far you can travel, you know?" He took a long drag of his cigarette before dropping the spent butt and grinding it under his boot. "I mean, don't you ever get tired, Miss Maria, of moving forward all the time. Like your soul is running out of gas?"
  • [["Yeah, I get that."|I get that]]
  • [["…I guess."|I guess][$go+=1]]

passages.name: bs f22
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Second FLoor, Rooms 204-210

The hallways stretched back towards the highway. The last fluorescent bulb was broken, throwing the furthest rooms into shadow. 210: Vacant 209: Vacant 208: Vacant [[207: OUR ROOM|bs 207]] 206: Vacant 205: Vacant 204: Vacant To the right, are the [[STAIRS|bs f11]] and the [[REST OF THE ROOMS.(201-203)|bs f21]].

passages.name: bs f21
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Second Floor, Rooms 101-103

The [[STAIRS|bs f11]] led back down to the first floor. To the right, there were three rooms: 203: Vacant 202: Vacant 201: Vacant After that, an ice machine sat in the spot where another room might have once been. The [[REST OF THE ROOMS (204-210)|bs f22]] stretch out to the left.

passages.name: you stay becky go out room
passages.text:
We got all of Becky's things in to the car just as the sun was peeking over the dusty mesa. She shut the trunk and turned to me. "It's not too late. Come with me?" She said, small, and scared and alone. But Lex was standing off to the side, chatting to Dean as he'd called her away. The two of them were lit up by the sunrise and the neon and they looked like everything I'd ever wanted. "Sorry, I'll call? I mean, I found the phone booth." I tried to joke. Becky just nodded, resigned, and got into the car. She drove away just as the sky was turning pink, leaving dust in her wake. I moved to Lex and Dean, sitting down on the curb between them as we watched the neon cactus bloom fade. "You girls are going to love it here," said Dean. "I promise." Lex looked at me, and reached for my hand. I took it. "You know what," I said. "I think we will."
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: just traveling
passages.text:
"…Just…traveling, I guess." Even though I couldn't sleep, I felt too tired to really explain too much. To be honest, I'd just rather listen, and sit in the cold desert night. He seemed to get that. "Aren't we all, Miss Maria?" He laughed at his dumb little joke. "But no, really. I think everyone at a motel is doing one of two things: moving or resting." He took a long drag of his cigarette before dropping the spent butt and grinding it under his boot. "You ever get tired, Miss Maria, of moving forward all the time. Like your soul is running out of gas?"
  • [["Yeah, I get that."|I get that]]
  • [["…I guess."|I guess][$go+=1]]

passages.name: lex bed
passages.text:
I went to bed next to Lex. She always fell asleep so quickly, and woke up the same way, as if she had a switch inside that just flipped on and off. It made sense though, almost like a natural extension of the way she always had a plan, always knew what to do. She could just say to her brain "Schedule: Sleep at 12:00 pm," and the body complied. I admired that about her. I mean, I certainly couldn't do that.
[[➥|insomnia]]

passages.name: ac
passages.text:
"At least it has AC." I said. Lex gestured at me as if I just proved her point. "See? It's fine. Besides, it's cheap and it looks pretty clean. What else can you really ask for?" "WiFi, Lex," said Becky. "We can ask for WiFi." "If you want to go down to the motel office and ask for it, be my guest." Lex said, pulling up the covers. "Me, I'm going to bed. Mari, just turn the lights out when you're done getting ready." "Yeah, of course," I said. The No-WiFi thing wouldn't be too bad. We'd be out of here by morning, after all, and the quicker morning came, the quicker we could keep going. But then again, the trip would end quicker that way too.
  • [[I fell asleep next to Lex.|lex bed]]
  • [[I fell asleep next to Becky.|becky bed]]

links.text: I fell asleep next to Lex.
I fell asleep next to Becky.

passages.name: already stay
passages.text:
"We don't need to convince her. She already wants to stay," I said. Becky stopped, her grip loose on my hands. "She does?" She sounded as surprised as I was; I just felt it for both of them. What was trying to keep them here? I, at least, had Houston to run away from. I had a flash, a moment when I realized I was her best friend, and I didn't know her at all. "She does. She's talking about maybe working on a website for the place or something." Becky wrinkled her nose. "Yeah, that sounds like Lex," she said. "Well, at least we'll have some time. Do you want to stick around for some TV?" I shook my head. There was still so much outside. And like she said, now we'd have some time.
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: dont smoke
passages.text:
"No thanks," I said. "I don't smoke." She huffed, taking the box back. "See if I'm ever nice again. But yeah, trap? Heh, maybe. It certainly snagged us, but you don't have to offer people the world to tempt them. They'll sell their souls for a lot less. A quiet night. A pack of smokes." She took a long, long drag. "Some people don't want to leave the cage though, you gotta remember that too." "Do you?" This time I knew she was looking at me. Her whole body turned, and she shook her head. "Does it look like the world has anything left for me?"
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: jackalope sent
passages.text:
"A jackalope sent me," I said, knowing it sounded super weird, and that I'd need to explain more. "He, uh, well he thinks this place is a trap, and that if I can find the books it can prove that nobody has ever left?" Lex looked at me. I looked back. She raised an eyebrow. I looked away. "Okay, first off I'm not even going to touch the whole jackalope thing. "But secondly, you know that doesn't make any sense, right? The books could be faked, or hidden, or a thousand other things. Lastly, it's just kind of ridiculous to think it's a trap. Wouldn't it be trying harder to keep us here, rather than just offering me a job? The place isn't exactly a paradise." I raised an eyebrow. "A job?" Lex grinned, all teeth. "Summer job. Pretty good pay, and free room and board. Get myself some cash before college, you know? Because this place is an opportunity, not a trap." I thought of the ugly curtains, the run down cars in the parking lot. I thought of the peace and the calm and the endless night sky.
  • [[Yeah, I guess it's not.|yeah guess not trap]]
  • [[But maybe it is?|maybe it is][$lex+=1]]

passages.name: bs parklot
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Parking Lot

[[BECKY'S CAR|bs beckys car]] was sitting in a spot near the west end of the motel and [[ROOMS 104-110|bs f12]]. There's a broken down sedan parked closer to the office and the [[OTHER FIRST FLOOR ROOMS.|bs f11]] Other than that, there's no one else in the lot. Just dust and gravel, and then [[THE HIGHWAY.|bs highway]]

passages.name: my parents
passages.text:
"We could call my parents?" I said. Becky frowned. "I guess, but what would we tell them? 'Hey mom, Hey dad, I found a magical motel and we're not going to Santa Monica?'" "Yeah, something like that," I said. "Maybe they'd be able to help." "They'd just want to convince you to leave. That and maybe they'd think you were crazy or doing drugs." She wiggled her fingers in a way that did not at all resemble doing drugs. "I really don't think they'd think that." They would be confused, sure, who wouldn't be but I don't think they'd jump that far. Then again, they were pretty happy I was staying home in Houston. I can't imagine they'd be receptive of the idea of me staying here.
    <>
  • [[911|911]]
    • <> <>
  • [[Aaron.|Aaron]]
    • <> <>
  • [[I don't know.|dont know call]]
    • <>

passages.name: brochures
passages.text:
The brochures advertise a whole range of places, from diners to drive-ins. My personal favorite was whole column of ads for different mini-golf courses including death metal mini-golf, thematically-similar-but-legally-distinct Godzilla mini-golf, and French Revolution mini-golf. The tiny guillotine chopping balls in half was a nice touch. Looking around at the motel now, all fuzzy and dream-like, I figured some of these places might be more real than previously expected.
[[➥|lobby]]

passages.name: rage becky
passages.text:
I felt rage bubble under my skin. She just didn't understand. How could she understand? She'd known what she wanted her whole life and this thing was Aaron was just a stepping block. Was this what friendship was supposed to be? Carving a place for yourself in someone else by hollowing out their secrets? I didn't know. I didn't know anything. "I'm not lying. It's just complicated," I said, cold and biting. "This is exactly why I didn't tell you, you know. You'd want to know and dissect and I don't even understand it." "It's not hard, Mari!" Becky said, arms wide and angry. "Just say "Becky, I think I'm gay!" "But I'm not!" I shouted, feeling heat rise up, as if the asphalt was giving it off and fueling my rage. "I don't know what I am! Bisexual, maybe, I don't know. Why does it even matter to you anyway?!" "I'm your friend! I'm supposed to know this stuff!" She said. "Yeah, like I'm supposed to know about you and Aaron having problems?" "That's different," she muttered. I swallowed, shaking my head. "Why? Cause you're leaving? I don't need to know anymore cause you're leaving anyway? Is that it?!" "No!" Becky said, quickly. Too quickly? I don't know. "I just didn't want to think about it."
  • [[Welcome to the party.|welcome to the party]]
  • [[Well maybe you should.|maybe talk][$becky+=1]]

passages.name: back to family
passages.text:
"I have to get back to my family." <>"The ones you only called once, and didn't say anything to?"<>"The one you haven't called all trip?"<> Trust me, they won't notice. That's just how this place works." "They will miss me," I said, voice shaking. His hand gripped mine tighter in comfort. "They would, because you're cool, but they won't because they won't be able to. It's not much a rest stop if people come hunt you down."
    <>
  • [[I have to start college.|college]]
    • <>
  • [["I have to start being an adult."|adult]]

links.text: "I have to start being an adult."

passages.name: don motel
passages.text:
"What's the deal with the motel?" Don Aquiles laughed, full bellied and warm. "The deal? Hmm, well I'm no scientist, but the word pocket dimension has been floated my way sometimes. But truly, it's what people need it to be. A place to rest, to refuel. Surely you've felt it?" I nodded. The light of the cactus bloom did feel oddly…refreshing.
    <>
  • [["Have you seen my keys?"|don keys]]
    • <><>
  • [["Do you think this place is a trap?"|don trap]]
    • <>
  • [["How did you end up here?"|don here]]
  • [["How long have you been working here?"|don working]]
  • [["What do you think of the guests?"|don guests]]
  • [[No more questions.|don no more q]]

links.text: "Do you think this place is a trap?"
"How long have you been working here?"
"What do you think of the guests?"

passages.name: bs lobby
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Lobby

The motel office was an empty square room, cut in half by a long counter that separated manager from guest. Behind the cheap faux-wood counter, there was a single door marked [[PRIVATE.|bs private]] On my side of the counter, there was a rack of [[BROCHURES|bs brochures]], folded and yellowed by wear and time, and a [[VENDING MACHINE|bs vending machine]], turned off. Then an open door towards [[THE ROOMS.|bs f11]]

passages.name: me music
passages.text:
The coke bottle rattled near my feet as I scrolled through my playlists, looking for something we could all enjoy. It was dark, but the road was empty, so who knew how much longer we'd be driving. And unless I picked something good, it'd be a few more hours of too much thinking.<> In the back seat, Becky was stretched out, scrolling on her phone, even though it was a dead zone. Her boyfriend back in Houston was hilarious, and reading Aaron's live-texts of his Star Wars marathon out loud was the only thing that got us out of Texas. But now it was just us, and the red rocks and dark sky.<> In the back seat, Lex had her legs tucked in under her, checking the maps and the route she'd planned. Our first idea had been to drive until we were tired, stop whenever we wanted, and eat only local. Lex let us keep all of that, as long as she could add a little bit more structure. Structure like neat, organized itineraries worthy of someone as type-A as she was. Still, we were off schedule now, just driving until we found a place to stay. Just us, and the red rocks and dark sky.<>
  • [[I'll never get tired of the desert.|tired]]
  • [[I was so sick of the desert.|sick]]

links.text: I'll never get tired of the desert.
I was so sick of the desert.

passages.name: becky music
passages.text:
Becky changed the music. She loved sitting shotgun, controlling the music and the A.C., her hands free to keep chatting on her phone. Her boyfriend back in Houston was hilarious, and reading his live-texts of his Star Wars Marathon out loud was the only thing that got us out of Texas. But it was no surprise that this stretch of desert was a dead zone. There would be no relief from the outside world here. All we had was our playlists and each other. <> I was in the backseat, trying not to think. It was hard. After, there was just us, and the red rocks and dark sky.<> In the backseat, Lex had her legs tucked in under her, checking the maps and the route she'd planned. Our first idea had been to drive until we were tired, stop whenever we wanted, eat only local. Lex let us keep all of that, as long as she could add a little bit more structure. Structure like neat, organized itineraries worthy of someone as type-A as she was. Still, we were off schedule now, just driving until we found a place to stay. Just us, and the red rocks and dark sky.<>
  • [[I'll never get tired of the desert.|tired]]
  • [[I was so sick of the desert.|sick]]

links.text: I'll never get tired of the desert.
I was so sick of the desert.

passages.name: becky convince her
passages.text:
"Maybe you could help me convince her? I mean, Pushing Daisies is pretty great." I said. I had very little confidence in anyone's ability to make Lex do anything. At least this way the blame wouldn't all end up on me. Becky shrugged. "She likes you better, and I'm pretty sure she's still mad that I ate the last BBQ chip yesterday." "She wouldn't hold a grudge like that," I said. Becky looked unimpressed. "Okay, well she wouldn't hold it this long. Besides, you have your reasons too." Becky smiled. It didn't reach her eyes. I had a flash, a moment when I realized I was her best friend, and I didn't know her at all. "Just, see what you can do, okay?" She asked. <> I heard a cart rumble in the hallway.<> "Alright, I'll see what I can do."
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: give it up
passages.text:
"Just give it up," I said, sighing. Even if he was right, and I still wasn't sure about that, his reason's didn't seem to make a lot of sense. "No! I'll prove it to you, I swear!" He hopped again, plucking a red cord with his antler. "Look!" The string led to a picture of Don Aquiles working at his desk, taken through the blinds of a window. It didn't show anything suspicious at all. "That picture doesn't prove much," I said. "Okay, so it's not the best quality, but it's what it represents! The Don keeps detailed logs of all the people who come in, if we could just find those, I could prove that no one has ever actually checked out!" There was something there, past the circled pictures and red string. Past the scratched out maps and dim light. There was something here that resonated with me. Maybe it all just felt too good to be true. Maybe that's what made me stay. "Okay, how can we get those logs?" I asked. The suspicions kept growing. Becky and Lex had accepted this way too easily. "Wait, you'll actually help me?" He said. Those ears didn't do much, I thought, but I nodded anyway. "Excellent! You could try his office I suppose, but he's in there more of the night. No our best bet is to get one of the old logs he keeps out in the shed in the desert."
  • [[What shed?|what shed]]

passages.name: what shed
passages.text:
"What shed?" I asked, looking for any details on the wall. There was an old chinese take out menu, but that wasn't relevant. "Out in the back, The Don keeps a shed full of supplies and mystery. You can get at it by just walking past the pool into the desert for a bit."

passages.name: dean motel
passages.text:
"What do you think of the motel?" "It's my favorite spot on this whole damn earth, that's what I think about it," he said. "How come?" He shrugged. "It just feels right, you know? Outside, the world is all rough edges and blaring lights. Here everything is fuzzy from the neon. It just feels right."
    <>

passages.name: okay stay
passages.text:
"Okay," I smiled back at him weakly. It felt like I'd just taken a huge step off a cliff, and I was rushing, rushing down. The only thing that felt real, and solid and here, was Dean's hand on mine. "That's great." He meant it. He was really so happy I'd stay. "That's so great." He left the keys in my hand now. "Go up, and leave these in the room. You won't need them anymore." <>
[[➥|pk parklot]]

passages.name: trap smoking
passages.text:
I sat down next to her, feet dangling off the railing before I asked. "Do you think this place is a trap?" She'd been doing her best to ignore me, but at my question she stilled, the smoke stopped curling and rose up straight. "Where'd you hear that?" She asked, almost nonchalant. The smoke kept smoking upwards. "The guy in 201. He's a rabbit, well a Jackalope. He, well… he thinks this place is a trap." She stayed still for a moment, before shifting, smoke trailing in her wake. She opened up her pack of Marlboros with a snap of a nail and knocked one out in front of me. "Have a smoke."
  • [["No thanks. I don't smoke."|dont smoke]]
  • [[I took the cigarette.|take smoke]]

passages.name: own the dvd
passages.text:
Well… Becky is the one who owns the DVDs. Guess I was wrong. "That's…cool," I said, feeling wrong-footed as Becky tossed herself onto the bed. "It was cancelled in Season 2!" Becky said, clutching the remote in glee. It was the most excited I'd seen her since she'd gotten her acceptance letter. "I don't really know how it works, but I'm not exactly going to complain." I peered over at the TV. Maybe they had more seasons of Veronica Ma— No, I had to focus. "Do you think we can convince Lex to stick around for an extra day or two, Mari? She left here as soon as the blue light came on, but I don't think she's seen this. We don't need to actually make it to California, right?" Becky clutched at my hands, desperate. "You should ask her. She never says no to you." "She always says no to me," I said. "She sometimes doesn't say no to you," Becky countered. Her eyes were bright. She wanted this. Badly.
  • [["I'll see what I can do."|becky see what do][$becky +=1]]
  • [["Maybe you could help me convince her?"|becky convince her]]
    • <>
  • [["She already wants to stay."|already stay]]
    • <>

links.text: "Maybe you could help me convince her?"

passages.name: not clever
passages.text:
"I'm not that clever," I said. Lex was the clever one. Becky was the smart one. I was…there. "Well of course not, you haven't driven away yet!" The Jackalope's black eyes burned with a fervor. "Don't you get it? This place is a trap. You need to leave before it's too late!" I looked at him in disbelief. Maybe I should have been since the start. "You don't believe me," he said. "No one ever believes me but look, LOOK!" He hopped over to the evidence wall, one antler tugging at a long red string. "See, the whole place is a trap. People check in, but they never check out!" I squint over at the wall. There are newspapers, some of them older than me, and photos, but nothing that seems decipherable. He must have noticed my confusion because he kept going. "Fine! I'll prove it to you!" "How?" I asked, but he was already convincing me just by having put the idea in my head. Pushing Daisies isn't that good. Lex could never give up on a schedule. "By showing you how trapped it is. You know phones don't work here. They don't want you reaching the outside world." His nose twitched, and he looked to the door, nervous that we'd be found. "But I still haven't tested the last one, the last phone. It's a pay phone, down east by the highway, still in the light of the motel. If I'm right, you could go out there, and it wouldn't let you call." "And if it does?" He already had me and he knew it. He seemed sure it wouldn't. I was less sure, about that, about anything. But now I had to check it out.
[[➥|f21]]

passages.name: vending machine
passages.text:
The vending machine was turned off, but it was quite possibly the strangest thing I'd ever seen before. It offered both Coke AND Pepsi. …Okay, this still might have been one of the weirder things here.
[[➥|lobby]]

passages.name: don aquiles first
passages.text:
"Maybe we should ask Don Aquiles first," I said, hesitant to jump into this but knowing I would anyway. It was inevitable. Lex was inevitable. "We can figure it out. Besides, it'd be better if we had a nugget to show him. Some kind of proof, don't you think? There has to be some kind of equipment or information somewhere. I mean, they dug the tunnel, didn't they?" I didn't say that they'd probably left the gold in the ground for a reason. She wouldn't listen. Instead, Lex would stay in this tunnel searching. I could go explore the rest<>.<>, and try and find the jackalope's books while I was at it.<>
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: 109 guests
passages.text:
"What do you think of the other guests?" He wrinkled his nose. "Odd sort. The woman smoking out on the balcony has terrible taste in literature, as does that boy in the parking lot. Come to think of it, The Band does too. Really the only one with any taste at all is up in 201." Sure. I'd never accept a book recommendation from 201 now, that's for sure.
    <>

passages.name: sorry smoking
passages.text:
"Uh… do you know your face is uh…." I fumbled, staring as she took a long drag of her cigarette. "Yeah, I know. It's fine. Don't worry about it. You new?" I nodded. "Yeah, me and my friends…" "Friends," She scoffed. "We'll see how they hold up. They got any reason to be sticking around?" Becky and Lex both had futures waiting out there. Fancy colleges, and lots of plans. "No, not really." "They'll probably check out tomorrow then, but you… you look like someone with a reason to stay. Are you?"
  • [["I am."|I am smoking]]
  • [["I don't know."|dont know smoking][$go+=1]]

passages.name: knowmean
passages.text:
"I know what you mean," I said. The whole motel felt unreal, like an Edward Hopper painting layered over real life. Realism, but not real. "Still… we must be here for a reason." She said, leaning back on the counter. "Maybe the universe just figured we needed a break?" I know I did. Lex looked away, out towards the parking lot and the clear night sky. She looked tired. The trip had run her down as well, I guessed. "Yeah, maybe it did."
    <>

passages.name: bs pool
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Pool

Flies buzzed inside an empty pool, echoing oddly into the night. Beyond it, [[THE DESERT|bs desert]] went on and on, until sky and ground are the same shade of inky, deep black. Behind me, [[THE MOTEL|bs f11]] stood, looking just as great as its pool.

passages.name: going on
passages.text:
"What's going on?" I said, unsure if I should be scared, in awe, or both. This desert had been an endless plain of nothingness, and here, where I thought there'd been maximum nothing, was something magical, something amazing. You'd never find something like this in Houston. I'm relatively sure you couldn't find something like this anywhere. Dean smiled, wild and careless, coming alive under the lights just as much as the rest of this place. "It's just the motel waking up. I know it's pretty shocking, I get surprised every time I see it too." "How many times have you seen it?" I asked. "Gosh, I dunno. I think I've lost count by now." He laughed, bright and joyful. In the hallway across from us, lights began to come on inside motel rooms, guests beginning to awaken. "But it never gets old, you never get tired of it. That's the beauty of this place: you never get tired." He stood up then, dusting the road off his jeans and reaching up towards the night sky in a single, sinuous stretch. "You should look around and make the most of it. See if you can't convince your friends to stay now."
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: 109 here
passages.text:
"How did you end up here?" I asked. "Oh, just stopped here on the highway on my way out to New York. I'm going to publish a novel there, as soon as I'm done." I didn't know you had to be in New York to publish, but that's none of my business.
    <>

passages.text:
I didn't have any more questions, but he let me know his door was open to me at any time.\n\n
[[➥|lobby]]

passages.name: something like what
passages.text:
"Something like what?" I asked. He smiled as much as a rabbit could and hopped again, plucking a red cord with his antler. "Look!" The string led to a picture of Don Aquiles working at his desk, taken through the blinds of a window. It didn't show anything suspicious at all. "That picture doesn't prove much," I said. "Okay, so it's not the best quality, but it's what it represents! The Don keeps detailed logs of all the people who come in, if we could just find those, I could prove that no one has ever actually checked out!" There was something there, past the circled pictures and red string. Past the scratched out maps and dim light. There was something here that resonated with me. Maybe it all just felt too good to be true. Maybe that's what made me stay. "Okay, how can we get those logs?" I asked. The suspicions kept growing. Becky and Lex had accepted this way too easily. "Wait, you'll actually help me?" He said. Those ears don't do much, I thought, but I nodded anyway. "Excellent! You could try his office I suppose, but he's in there more of the night. No our best bet is to get one of the old logs he keeps out in the shed in the desert."
  • [[What shed?|what shed]]
  • [[What am I looking for?|looking]]
  • [[I could just ask.|just ask]]
  • [[I'm ready.|im ready]]

passages.name: sick
passages.text:
There's something awful about the desert, massive, unchanging and unwelcoming. It's like the world is designing a place to either get rid of you, or trap you there forever. But in every desert, there is an oasis. Neon lights cast a green glow on the horizon, rising like a premature dawn. As we got closer, we could see the shape resolve into a giant neon cactus. Below it, the words "CACTUS BLUE MOTEL" blazed before a background of dark desert sky.
[[➥|intro lot]]

passages.name: notordinary
passages.text:
"I don't think you're ordinary, Lex." There was nothing ordinary about her. But at the same time, it wasn't the same kind of difference as the motel. Lex was real, driven, determination made flesh. This place, it was a dream. It almost didn't make sense that Lex wanted to stay. "You know what I mean, Mari," she said, not even picking up on the compliment. Just steamrolling forward. "Real people. Not some chosen one in a bad anime." "Well it's happening to us anyway," I said. She nodded, not able to argue the point, but she just teased, undeterred. "Well, if any of us is the chosen one, I bet it's Becky. She's the only one with colorful hair."
    <>
  • [[I asked her what she thought about Don Aquiles.|lex aquiles 1]]
    • <> <>
  • [[I asked about Becky.|lex becky 1]]
    • <>
  • [[I left her to keep exploring.|leave Lex]]

links.text: I asked her what she thought about Don Aquiles.
I left her to keep exploring.

passages.name: you stay becky go room
passages.text:
Becky paused, and shook her head. "I can't stay. I just can't. I need to go back out and talk to Aaron, to start school."

Lex paused, and looked away. "I need the time, just a bit. It won't be for long."

I looked at Lex, shocked that she was staying with me. Becky was just as surprised, and she looked about to cry.

"It won't be forever," I said quickly. But who knew anymore. She must have seen something in my face, in my stance, that showed that I wasn't about to move on this, and slumped. 

"We'll help you pack," I said, and we did. They needed to go before sunrise, and we all hurried [[OUT OF THE ROOM.|you stay becky go out room]]

destination.name: you stay becky go out room

passages.name: shelves 2
passages.text:
Here, there were more shelves filled with old sign-in books. Some names were normal. Some names leapt out: Lucille Ball (6/12/32 - 6/14/32), Elvis Presley (4/3/53 - 4/4/53), and Washington Irving (12/31/16-1/1/19). Really old sign-in books. I found only a few with open dates. Lydia with no last name (12/24/70), A fancy, but unintelligible signature (7/3/1984). No Dean. <>
[[➥|tunnel door]]

passages.name: bs vending machine
passages.text:
The vending machine was turned off, but it was quite possibly the strangest thing I'd ever seen before. It offered both Coke AND Pepsi. This place was weird.
[[➥|bs lobby]]

passages.name: keys gone
passages.text:
"They're gone." I felt cold, for the first time since arriving in the desert. I tried to think logically. Had I taken them out of the room? Had I ever had them in the first place? I couldn't remember. He could see the panic in my face, and he relished in it. "Yeah, they're gone. Look, if you like, but I bet you won't find them. I bet you won't ever find them."
[[➥|f21]]

passages.name: play
passages.text:
Somewhere in the Desert, Between New Mexico and Arizona - The Summer After High School

We left Houston two days ago, heading west along the back roads to California. An empty bottle of Mexican Coke kept rolling around the passenger side. And only now, in the dark, did a cool desert breeze start to push away the summer heat. It was our last trip together, just the three of us. In two weeks, Becky would be off at Stanford, Lex at NYU, and me… well, I'd still be in Houston. But for now, the only things we had to think about were the open road, the starry skies, and the 750 miles left to Santa Monica.
  • [[I was driving.|me drive]]
  • [[Lex was driving.|lex drive]]
  • [[Becky was driving.|becky drive]]

passages.name: dean long
passages.text:
"How long have you been here?" Dean smiled, cigarette hanging in his teeth. "Oh, since I was 19." He didn't look a day over 20, so I really had to wonder how long he'd been 19.

passages.name: becky drive
passages.text:
Becky was driving. Even though it was her car, it was pretty rare for her to be behind the wheel. She preferred to sit shotgun, controlling the music, her hands free to keep chatting on her phone. Her boyfriend back in Houston was hilarious, and reading Aaron's live-texts of his Star Wars marathon out loud was the only thing that got us out of Texas. But it was no surprise that this stretch of desert was a dead zone. There would be no relief from the outside world here. All we had was our playlists and each other. And the playlists were debatable. Becky's fingers twitched on the wheel. "Can we please change the music? I can't believe I'm saying this, but I'm kind of sick of Hamilton."
  • [[I changed the music.|me music]]
  • [[Lex changed the music.|lex music]]

passages.name: hotel generous
passages.text:
"Hotel is a little generous, don't you think?" I said. "It's a motel." Lex just rolled her eyes. "Motel, hotel, whatever it is it's cheap and it looks pretty clean. What else can you really ask for?" "WiFi, Lex," said Becky. "We can ask for WiFi." "If you want to go down to the motel office and ask for it, be my guest," Lex said, pulling up the covers. "Me, I'm going to bed. Mari, just turn the lights out when you're done getting ready." "Yeah, of course." I said. The No-WiFi thing wouldn't be too bad. We'd be out of here by morning, after all, and the quicker morning came, the quicker we could keep going. But then again, the trip would end quicker that way too.
  • [[I fell asleep next to Lex.|lex bed]]
  • [[I fell asleep next to Becky.|becky bed]]

links.text: I fell asleep next to Lex.
I fell asleep next to Becky.

passages.name: you go both stay out room
passages.text:
We walked fast, the sun already peeking past the dusty mesa in the distance, and piled everything into the car. Shutting the trunk, Lex walked up to me. "Not too late to change your mind," she said. I paused. I wondered, if I said something, would she ask me to stay with her. To stay by her side. But I didn't ask, and neither did she. Behind her, Dean frowned, disappointed. "I'll be okay." The sky was already turning pink by the time I drove off. In the rearview mirror, I could see the cactus bloom, flicker one, twice, and fade. The motel went out of sight shortly after. I fixed my eyes on the highway, long and lonely. I turned on the radio. I had to do something, after all. There were still 750 miles left to Santa Monica.
[[➥ END|end credits]]

passages.name: lex music
passages.text:
Lex changed the music. While she preferred to be driving, she also enjoyed having control over the music, or anything at all. Our first idea for the trip had been to drive until we were tired, stop whenever we wanted, eat only local. Lex let us keep all of that, as long as she could add a little bit more structure. Structure like neat, organized itineraries worthy of someone as type-A as she was. Still, we were off schedule now, just driving until we found a place to stay.<> I was in the backseat, trying not to think. It was hard. After, there was just us, and the red rocks and dark sky.<> In the back seat, Becky was stretched out, scrolling on her phone, even though it was a dead zone. Her boyfriend, Aaron, back in Houston had been providing a running commentary for most of the drive so far (Including a hilarious live-text of the Star Wars movies). But now it was just us, and the red rocks and dark sky.<>
  • [[I'll never get tired of the desert.|tired]]
  • [[I was so sick of the desert.|sick]]

links.text: I'll never get tired of the desert.
I was so sick of the desert.

passages.name: becky quarter no
passages.text:
Becky looked at me, then back at the quarter. "What?" "You need this more than I do. You actually have someone to talk to on the outside," I said. Becky looked back at the impossible phone booth, here in the middle of nowhere, then back at the quarter. She seemed more frightened of the quarter than of anything else we'd seen tonight. "You're the one who said talking is good." I reminded her. "Not now. Not like this. I can talk to him later," she said, taking a step back. She wasn't going to call, I could tell. Still, I needed to check if the phone worked. She waited for me outside the glass, as I marked my parents' number. My mom picked up, worried. I shivered at the sound of her voice, even as I reassured her nothing was wrong. Just homesick, though I wasn't sure I'd ever felt anything less like homesickness. I lied and lied, and hung up. Guess the jackalope was wrong. The phone did work. Afterward, we walked back in silence. Back under the glow of the motel lights, Becky left quickly, not even looking at Dean. "I'll see you back at the room," she said. I just nodded. It wasn't like she was going anywhere at all. <>
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: jack 2
passages.text:
I walked in, slowly, cautiously. It was dark, sheets thrown over lamps to prevent their full brightness. Papers were scattered over the beds and the floor, covered in mad scribbles. On the far wall, maps and photos were pinned to the wall, red string forming a spiderwebs between locations. A picture of Dean was circled three times in red pen. Normally, I'd have been weirded out by the paranoia wall, but by then I'd gotten a good look at who'd opened the door. It was a rabbit, with antlers. I said so, and the rabbit scoffed, "I'm a Jackalope, thank you very much. There's a difference." "Yeah, the antlers." The rab… Jackalope leapt up onto the bed, while giving me the side eye. I didn't know rabbit eyes could do that. "Yeah, bet you think you're so clever. Well, you ended up here, so ha! Joke's on you."
  • [["I'm not that clever."|not clever]]
  • [["What do you mean by that?"|what mean]]
  • [["Are you even allowed on the furniture?"|furniture]]

links.text: "Are you even allowed on the furniture?"

passages.name: jack 1
passages.text:
The sign on the door said DO NOT DISTURB. I knocked anyway. There was a rustling, a thump, a shout. "DORIS FOR THE LAST TIME, I DON'T NEED THE ROOM CLEANED!" "It's not Doris," I said, already starting to regret this. "Oh damn," The voice inside said. Chains jingled. "You're new, aren't you?" He didn't give me time to answer as the lock clicked, and the door swung open. "Come in, come in! I have so much to tell you." <>
[[➥|jack 2]]

passages.name: how deep
passages.text: I finally (finally) hit the ground and looked back up. The light from the shed above was a distant star, barely visible in the dim orange glow in the tunnel.\n\nAnd at the bottom, in the glow of that star [[LEX.|lex bunker]]

passages.name: becky come with me
passages.text:
"Yeah. Come with me?" It would be nice, if she did. I'd like some company out by the lonely highway. Becky sighed, looking between me, the door and the TV. "You don't have to," I said, already heading for my bag. "No, no. Of course I'll go." She pulled on her hoodie, two sizes too big, and that was that. "I'll meet you outside, okay?" "…Okay."
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: i cant stay
passages.text:
"I can't stay," I said. Sometimes the hardest thing to say was the truth. His hands tightened on mine for just a moment, almost crushing, then let go, leaving the keys inside them. "You know you won't find anything good out there, right? You won't ever find anything like this." I knew that. I knew it, but I had to leave anyway. I couldn't just run from the real world, no matter how much the Cactus Blue had given me the opportunity. "I know." He huffed, pulling away. I was cold, and alone, in the desert. "Fine, then go. Take them and go. You'll regret it later." <>
[[➥|pk parklot]]

passages.name: bs desert
passages.text:
Somewhere in the distance, a coyote howled. Yeah, I wasn't heading out there like this.\n\n
[[➥|bs pool]]

passages.name: don working
passages.text:
"How long have you been working here?" "Ohh, maybe two hundred years." He said. I sat there, mouth open, as he shrugged. "Working here has some perks, you know. It lets you keep a much better idea of time than some of the others. I don't regret a minute though. This place is a gift."
    <>

passages.text:
I didn't have any more questions. "Come jam with us whenever!" The Singer said. The rest of them seemed to agree in their silence.
[[➥|f11]]

passages.name: boxes 2
passages.text:
Inside the boxes were some old fliers and posters in different styles. Ads for the Cactus Blue in the 50's, the 70's, and what looked like the 1890's. Had any of these ever run? At the bottom of the piles, there was a flier, faded and yellowed that read: █████'S GREAT TREASURES WORLD'S LARGEST PYRITE VEIN DON'T BE MADE A FOOL BY FOOL'S GOLD AND COME TO THE CACTUS BLUE MOTEL. <>Huh, that's pretty cool. It's probably down here in the tunnels somewhere.<>Oh. Lex's dream (my dream) vanished with a stroke of ink. There's no way that vein was ever real. I had to tell her.<>
[[➥|tunnel door]]

passages.name: managers office
passages.text:
Someone was speaking behind the door. A deep voice, warm like a desert night, and then a higher, smoother tone that I recognized: Lex. <>I didn't realize Lex had left the room. <>I couldn't make out what she said, but her voice was unmistakable. I knocked. The first voice chimed in, responding to Lex and not to me. It sounded like a pretty intense conversation.
  • [[I'd come back when I had more stories to convince her to stay.|lobby]]
    • <=3>>
  • [[I knocked again.|knock]]
    • <>

links.text: I'd come back when I had more stories to convince her to stay.

passages.name: bloom
passages.text:
Neon bloomed into the desert. It started small, like a flickering star, but it began to grow, as if neon tubes were being spawned from nothing. Above the cactus, a blue flower began to grow, petals spread towards the night sky. And the hotel bloomed with it. Dingy railings now freshly painted. Door plaques glimmered. And cars began appearing in the parking lot, as if they'd been there all along, and it only took the blue light of the motel sign to make them visible. Dean, bathed in the glow, smiled. "Worth waiting for, isn't it?"
  • [["It's beautiful."|beautiful]]
  • [["What the hell is going on?"|going on]]
  • [["This has to be a dream."|dream]]

passages.name: desert
passages.text:
Somewhere in the distance, a coyote howled again. I wasn't going out there for no reason.<<if visited("post phonebooth jack") and $bunker==false>>

I could see in the distance now, a pool of light around an old metal [[SHED|bunker]].<<endif>>

Behind me, [[THE MOTEL|pool]] shone, a lone light in the dark.

passages.name: pool
passages.text:
The Cactus Blue Motel - Pool

Everything about the pool hit just the right note. The water was a brilliant blue under the cactus bloom. The filters bubbled soothingly, filling in the sound of an empty night. Perfect beach chairs, each with a soft towel lined the pool, and even the chlorine smell was just right, making the night feel clean and pure. Beyond that, [[THE DESERT|desert]] stretched out into nothingness. This place really was an oasis. Behind me, [[THE MOTEL|f11]] stood, looking just as amazing as its pool.

passages.name: no reason
passages.text:
"No reason," I said, keeping it all to myself. She didn't need the doubts, the mystery. I couldn't do much, but I could protect her from that. Lex looked at me fondly, like she was glad I was here, glad I'd just decided to be here with her. I blushed and looked away. "I mean though, if you have any idea where those record books are, I'd appreciate it." I said. "No, sorry. Don Aquiles hasn't trusted me with that yet. He says it'll come after I sign the contract." I raised an eyebrow. "Contract?" Lex grinned, all teeth. "Summer job. Pretty good pay, and free room and board. Get myself some cash before college, you know?" "So you want to stay? What if it's a trap?!" I said. Lex looked at me. I looked back. She raised an eyebrow. I looked away. "You know that doesn't make any sense at all, right? Wouldn't it be trying harder to keep us here if it was? The place isn't exactly a paradise." I thought of the ugly curtains, the run down cars in the parking lot. I thought of the peace and the calm and the endless night sky.
  • [[Yeah, I guess it's not.|yeah guess not trap]]
  • [[But maybe it is?|maybe it is][$lext+=1]]

passages.name: becky stay
passages.text:
"Yeah, but you can stay if you like." I could see her reluctance. It hurt, a little. But I knew I wasn't that important. She paused, looking at me, then at the TV. "No. No I'll come with you." She seemed to be trying to convince herself. She pulled on her hoodie, two sizes too big, and hesitated. "I'll meet you outside, okay?" "…Okay."
[[➥|f22]]

passages.name: stay on schedule
passages.text:
"We should get up early and stay on schedule." I said, as we stepped out of the car. Lex turned to me, lips barely curled in a smile. I smiled back. Becky just let out a sigh.

"Fiiiine," she said. She knew she was outnumbered.

Looking up, I took in the motel sign again. We'd seen several like it on our trip here. Googie architecture, it was called. Swooping lines and visions of yesterday's future.

This one was a little more boring than most. The sign didn't even seem to be animated.

Still, all we needed was a place to stay. We took our bags, and walked into the [[MOTEL OFFICE|arriving at lobby]].

passages.name: I am smoking
passages.text:
"I guess I am," I said, thinking of how tired I felt, and how little I knew about what was to come. "But it's not exactly an option, you know." "Why not?" She blew out a puff of smoke from her puff of smoke. It looked pretty weird. "Well, My friends won't want to and we came together," I said. "Not like you'll need a ride." "And it costs money." "Not after the first night," she said. I stopped. "What?" "Yeah, no cost after night one. Or did you think we all had the cash to stick around?" I hadn't thought of it, but obviously she knew plenty about the motel. Maybe I should ask her stuff.
    <>

passages.name: band while
passages.text:
"I was in band for a while," I said lamely. I played the flute badly. "Perfect! Over here," She shuffled me towards the instruments and handed me a guitar. "I didn't play the gui—" She didn't let me finish as she grabbed my shoulders. "Doesn't matter. We just want your new sound, fresh, you know!" She was beaming. The Drummer counted down with his sticks. I could almost hear it in my head: FIVE, SIX, SEVEN, EIGHT! And we played. Even me. The sound just seemed to spill from the guitar, amateurish, sure, but still recognizable. I couldn't say now, what kind of song we played, only that there was music, and fury, and the thunder of cymbals. In the end, we all flopped down, grinning. The Singer smiled. "Nice. You added some great sound. Will you be stickin' around to jam with us some more?
  • [["Yeah, probably."|yes band]]
  • [["Don't think so."|no band][$go +=1]]
  • [["What just happened?"|happened band]]

passages.name: maybe
passages.text:
"Yeah," I said, pushing myself up. "Maybe. You going to head to bed anytime tonight?" Dean smiled and shook his head. "The night's just getting started. In fact," he stopped, looking at his wrist-watch. "The cactus is about to bloom." Here he gestured out towards the hotel sign, a three pronged-cactus lit up in tacky neon-green. But that's all there was. There was no glint or extra neon tubing to herald a bloom, or even any animation. But as I watched, it happened anyway.
[[➥|bloom]]

passages.name: thunderbird
passages.text:
<>I looked over, and under and maybe a little too closely AT the thunderbird, but my keys weren't around here either.<>I didn't know anything about cars, but I knew this was a nice one. Old, with those classic wings and a stunning blue paint job that seemed to shine from within under the neon lights. I reached out a hand and touched the coat of paint lightly. Just… wow. I think I finally got why people loved cars.<>
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: 109 long
passages.text:
"How long have you been here?" He paused, tapping the pages to the bottom of his lip. "A few years. I think." His wardrobe said a few decades. "I'm not sure though," he continued. "Time's a little odd here, you know?" "I don't." "Oh. Well, you will."

passages.name: lex becky 1
passages.text:
"So have you spoken to Becky?" I asked. Lex shook her head. "She's been acting weird for a while, said she wanted to stay in the room after the blue light turned on. I think something's going on." I frowned. I hadn't really noticed anything. "Like what?" Lex shrugged. "I'm no psychic. But she obviously doesn't want to talk about it, or else she would have. Not like we have that much to do on the drive, right?"

"… What about the guy in room 201?" Dean sat forward slightly, eye narrowing, the burn of the cigarette reflected in it. "That guy? Pathetic. Everyone else at least takes advantage of this place but he hates it. But you don't see him leaving, do you? What an idiot." "…Well he is a rabbit." I said. "A Jackalope, and that's no excuse."

passages.name: some trap reveal
passages.text:
I moved closer, slowly, placing a hand on her back. "It'll be okay, Lex." I said, once again proving my capacity to say exactly the wrong thing. "It's not going to be okay! It's never going to be okay, because the gold is fake and the salary isn't good enough and I'm going to be in debt until I die!!!" I jumped back as she lashed out, losing her cool composure, her calm, her everything I admired about her. "What?" She ran her fingers across her scalp, shaking her head. "I just… NYU's expensive. I was hoping that maybe I could… I don't know, find something here to help pay it off." "Like the job from Don Aquiles," I said numbly. "yeah, like that." She let out a lingering sigh, before shaking herself off. "Let's…let's just go, okay?" I nodded. "Yeah, whatever you need." <>
[[➥|forward]]

passages.name: im ready
passages.text:
"Okay, I think I'm ready," I said. "Good, now head out and find some proof. You'll find it, I'm sure. There's no other reason people would stay here this long." I just nodded, though I wasn't sure about that. But then again, doubt was what had me on this hunt in the first place.
[[➥|f21]]

passages.name: dream
passages.text:
"This has to be a dream," I said. Nothing else made sense. This desert had been an endless plain of nothingness, and here, where I thought there'd been maximum nothing, was something magical, something amazing. You'd never find something like this in Houston. I'm relatively sure you couldn't find something like this anywhere. Dean smiled, wild and careless, coming alive under the lights just as much as the rest of this place. "You'd think that, but no. It's just always this great. No matter how many times I've seen it." "How many times have you seen it?" I asked. "Gosh, I dunno. I think I've lost count by now." He laughed, bright and joyful. In the hallway across from us, lights began to come on inside motel rooms, guests beginning to awaken. "But it never gets old, you never get tired of it. That's the beauty of this place: you never get tired." He stood up then, dusting the road off his jeans and reaching up towards the night sky in a single, sinuous stretch. "You should look around and make the most of it. See if you can't convince your friends to stay now."
[[➥|parklot]]

passages.name: listen to me
passages.text:
But I knew she would listen to me. We had the advantage of time, of closeness. She'd hear me out, I just knew it. I opened the door, to find that she was on the other side, like she had been about to open it as well. "Mari! Come in, you won't believe this," she said, yanking me inside of the room. It looked exactly the same as before. Same painting of red rock mesa. Same weird colored motel comforter. Same ancient blocky TV, only now it was on. "Look!" Becky pointed at the screen. Kristin Chenoweth was running around a colorful pie shop. "Nice," I said. "I didn't know they were playing reruns of Pushing Daisies." Becky shook her head. "They aren't. It's Season 3." I stopped, and looked back at the screen.
  • [["But it got cancelled after Season 2."|season 2]]
  • [[Well… Becky is the one who owns the DVDs. Guess I was wrong.|own the dvd][$becky+=1]]

links.text: Well… Becky is the one who owns the DVDs. Guess I was wrong.

passages.name: adult
passages.text:
"I have to go and be an adult," I said. That was the reality of things. That was what it all boiled down to. Dean only smiled. "No, you don't. You don't have to do anything like that ever again. I promise. Just… stay?"
  • [[...Okay|okay stay]]
  • [[...I can't|i cant stay]]
